form.definition: noun L or l is the twelfth letter of the English alphabet.

dictionary.entry: l symbol for litre or litres.
L symbol for learner driver. ... SEE THE PICTURE at L-plate.

form.definition: abbreviation for lane. It is usually used when you write an address.[qr

dictionary.entry:
label`lEIb@l
noun A label is a piece of paper with writing on it which is attached to an object in order to give information about it. The label on my suitcase has my name, address and phone number. The label says the coat is pure wool. I checked the list of ingredients on the label.
... WORD FAMILYverb label (labels, labelled, labelling) I labelled each file with the date. The bottle is labelled 'POISON'.

form.definition: noun Labor means the Australian Labor Party. The polls show Labor has a narrow lead over the Liberal Party. I'm going to vote Labor this time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective Labor ...a Labor voter. ...the Labor candidate.

dictionary.entry: laboratoryl@`bOr@tri:laboratories noun A laboratory is a room or building where scientists carry out experiments using specialised equipment. The doctor sent the urine samples to the laboratory to be analysed. ... A SHORTENED FORM of this word is lab.

form.definition: noun The Labor Party is another name for the Australian Labor Party.

noun Labour is hard work, especially physical work. It was good to see the garden looking nice after all our labour. Costas has been working on the problem for ages but has little to show for his labours.
noun Labour also refers to workers collectively. There is a shortage of skilled labour. Management and labour are working together to save the company.
noun Labour is the physical effort of giving birth to a child. Ellie went into labour in the morning and the baby was born at midnight.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING for this word is labor. ... WORD FAMILY verb labour (or labor) We laboured in the hot sun all day.noun labourer (or laborer) He found work as a builders labourer.[qr

dictionary.entry:
lacelEIs
1 noun Lace is a thin, delicate fabric made up of an ornamental pattern of threads and spaces. Maria put up lace curtains to make the room more private.
noun A lace is a piece of cord which you thread through holes in order to fasten something. I tripped over one of my shoe laces.
verb If you lace something or lace it up, you fasten it by pulling the ends of a lace tight and knotting them. I knelt down to lace my shoe. The dress laces up at the back=ma zip would be a lot less trouble!
verb If you lace a drink, you add alcoholic spirits or a drug to it. They must have laced his lemonade with something stronger, because he seemed pretty drunk before the party ended.
... WORD FAMILY adjective lace ...a lace tablecloth. adjective lacy ...a pair of lacy knickers.

form.definition: verb If something lacerates your skin, it makes several cuts and scratches in it. The broken windscreen lacerated his face.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun laceration The only effect of the accident was a deep laceration on his arm.

form.definition: 1 noun If there is a lack of something, you do not have enough of it, or you do not have any of it. I was unable to contact him due to lack of time. One of the problems we face is the lack of funding. They showed a remarkable lack of interest in the scheme.
verb If you lack something, you don't have enough of it, or you don't have any of it. The search party lacked food and supplies. We lack the resources to undertake such an ambitious project.
verb If something lacks a quality, it does not possess it. It is not characterised by it. The movie lacked suspense. His words lacked conviction.
3 lacking If something is lacking, it does not exist or there is not enough of it. I'm afraid our safety record is lacking a bit, and we'll have to improve that very quickly.
lacking in If someone or something is lacking in something, they have less of it than they should have. Syed is lacking in initiative. This curry is rather lacking in taste.
noun Lacquer is a hard, shiny varnish which is applied to wood or metal to protect it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb lacquer

form.definition: noun A lad is a boy or young man. Simon's a nice lad. When I was a lad I used to swim in the dam. I often go for a drink with the lads after the game.[qr

dictionary.entry:
ladder`lAd@
noun A ladder is a tall structure consisting of two wooden or metal supports with bars (called fixed between them at regular intervals. You lean the ladder against something and climb up or down it by stepping on the rungs. b noun Some ladders have flat steps instead of rungs, and they have supporting legs on hinges so you don't need to lean them against something. These ladders are usually called stepladders.
rungs
noun A ladder in your stocking or pantihose is a long, thin hole where the vertical threads are broken.
... WORD FAMILYverb ladder I laddered my stockings on the edge of the chair.

form.definition: noun Lady is a polite way of referring to a woman. Often you use it to refer, in her presence, to a woman whose name you don't know. I believe this lady was here before me. Would the lady in the red coat please come forward.
2 ladies A ladies is a women's toilet in a public place. I'll just go to the ladies.
3 ladies and gentlemen People use ladies and gentlemen as a way of beginning a speech or announcement to a group of people. Ladies and gentlemen, I am delighted to introduce our special guest star.

verb If someone or something lags, they fail to keep up with others. Inga was lagging back in tenth place. My swollen ankle forced me to lag further and further behind. Australia must not lag behind other nations in developing this technology.
noun Lager is a type of beer. It is pale in colour and contains bubbles of gas.
noun A lagoon is an area of water separated from the sea by a sand bank or reef.
is the past tense form of the verb lay.
noun A lake is a large area of water surrounded by land.
noun Lamb is the meat that comes from a young sheep.
adjective If you are lame, you can't walk properly. You limp. Natasha will be lame for life as a result of the car accident. Trent's horse had gone lame.
adjective If an excuse or a joke is lame, it is not convincing or not funny. I've never heard such a lame excuse in my life.
verb If you laminate a photograph or document, you cover it tightly with a thin layer of plastic in order to protect it.

2 laminated If something is laminated, it is made up of several thin layers of material like plastic or wood. The kitchen workbenches are laminated wood. The windscreen is laminated glass, so it won't break into thousands of pieces.
noun A lamington is a small square of sponge cake which has a layer of chocolate and coconut on the outside.[qr

noun A lamp is a light. It is powered by electricity, or sometimes by oil or kerosene. Muoi sat next to the reading lamp in the lounge room. He was carrying a kerosene lamp because the electricity was off.
noun Land is the area of the Earth's surface not covered by water. We flew over land and sea. At last the sailors sighted land.
noun Land is a particular area of ground. He turned the land surrounding his house into a beautiful garden. The land is very fertile around here. The station covers thousands of hectares of land.
noun In rather literary language, you can call a country a land. Australia is a beautiful land. He travelled for many years in foreign lands.
verb If you are travelling by boat or plane, when you land, you arrive somewhere. We landed at one of the smaller islands to spend the night. Their flight has just landed.

verb If something lands somewhere, it comes to rest there. Our ball landed in the neighbour's yard. The kite landed in a tree. They spin the wheel and if the ball lands against your number, you win. Why has this file landed on my desk again?
verb If you land something, you bring it onto the shore. I landed the boat on the beach and pulled it up on the sand. It was a real struggle to land the fish.
verb In informal language, if you say you land something, you mean that you manage to get it. Petra landed a great job last week.
7 the land The land is the country, as distinct from the city. She lives out west somewhere, on the land. The National Party traditionally draws its support from the land.
noun Your landlady is the woman who owns the property in which you live. She allows you to live there in return for rent.
noun Your landlord is the man who owns the property in which you live. He allows you to live there in return for rent.

noun A landmark is something that can be easily seen and recognised. It helps you to know where you are. The Opera House is a famous Sydney landmark. I chose the church tower as my landmark and headed towards it.

noun A landmark is also an event which marks a stage in history or in the development of something. Federation was a landmark of Australia's history. The first time I swam 100 metres was a real landmark for me.
noun The landscape is what you see when you look across the land. The landscape is very flat around here. Tasmania has some beautiful landscapes. The industrial landscape of Melbourne is changing.
noun A landscape is a painting or photograph of an area of land. Frederick McCubbin painted many Australian landscapes.
verb If someone landscapes an area of land, they design and create an attractive park or garden. We have plans to landscape our backyard.
noun A landslide happens when part of the earth and rocks on a mountain or cliff gives way and falls down the slope. The heavy rain caused a landslide across the mountain road.
noun In politics, a landslide happens when one person or party receives a very large majority of the votes. In 1983 there was a landslide to Labor.
noun A lane is a narrow road or path. You can park in the lane at the back of the house. I live at 23 Banksia Lane.

noun Major roads are divided into lanes in order to control the flow of traffic. Each lane is a track wide enough for one vehicle only. White lines are painted on the road to mark the different lanes. You should always use the right-hand lane when overtaking. They're building a new six-lane highway.

noun Language is the human system of communication. It is made up of words which are arranged in a certain order to give meaning. There are many different languages in the world. Chang can speak three languages fluently.
noun Language is also any set of signs which have a definite meaning. I learnt to program in several different computer languages. I could see from his body language that he wasn't happy about it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See linguistic.

form.definition: adjective Hair that is lank is straight and limp.
adjective If someone is lanky, they are tall and thin. Efrem is a very lanky young man.
noun In former times, a lantern was a kind of lamp that you could carry round. The light was protected by glass set in a metal frame.
noun Lao is the language spoken in Laos and part of Thailand.
adjective If someone or something comes from Laos, you describe them as Lao.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is Laotian.

form.definition: noun When you sit down, your lap is the part of your body that is horizontal, from your hips to your knees. She let the toddler climb onto her lap. Cats like to sleep on a warm lap. I dropped a piece of cake in my lap.
noun In a race, a lap is a single circuit of the course. Fabio is almost half a lap ahead of the others. I do three laps of the oval every morning to keep in shape.
noun In a swimming race, a lap is one length of the pool.
verb If water laps against something, it washes against it in small waves. We could hear the water lapping against the side of the boat.

lap up (a) Animals lap up liquid when they drink, using their tongue. The cat lapped up all the milk. (b) If you lap up praise or attention, you enjoy getting it very much. I lapped up all their compliments.

noun A lapse is a temporary slip or failure. Nino had a lapse of concentration and drove off the road. I've been suffering from memory lapses lately. The error was just a lapseshe's normally very careful.

noun A lapse is a period of time between things happening. There was a lapse of ten years before he married again. The disease flares up for a few months at a time, with long lapses in between. I took up swimming again after the winter lapse.

verb If something lapses, it is not valid any more. It is out of date. The offer will lapse at the end of the year. I let my membership lapse. If your driver's licence has lapsed by more than two years, you have to take the test again.
verb If someone lapses into a certain state, they fall or drift into that state. Vishal lapsed into unconsciousness. She lapsed into incoherence because she was so angry.

adjective If something is large, it is big. We want to move to a larger house. He was accompanied by a large dog. She gave me a large bunch of flowers. The surgeon removed a large tumour. Education is a large issue.

adjective If an amount or quantity is large, it is great. A large number of people turned up. I have a large amount of freedom. There's a large difference between the two. She earns a much larger salary in her new job.
2 at large If a dangerous person or animal is at large, they have escaped. They are free and roaming in an area. Police warned the public that three of the escaped prisoners were still at large.

3 by and large By and large means 'on the whole'. You mean that what you say is true in most cases, although there may be some exceptions. By and large voters are not interested in the referendum issue. They seem satisfied with their decision, by and large.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun largeness

form.definition: noun A larrikin is a man who has little respect for authority and behaves in a noisy, boisterous way. He knocks around with a bunch of larrikins.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective larrikin He's gone out with his larrikin mates. He has a certain larrikin charm.

form.definition: noun If you have laryngitis, you have a sore and inflamed throat, and a swollen larynx which makes you temporarily lose your voice.

dictionary.entry:
larynx`lArINks; <plural > /\times,0\lrndiz, lrksz/ larynges\minion0\or\optima0\larynxes
noun Your larynx is the top part of the passage from your throat to your lungs. It contains your vocal cords.

form.definition: noun A laser is a device which creates a narrow beam of intense concentrated light. The beam can be used to cut metal and can also be used instead of a knife in surgery.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective laser ...a laser beam. ...a laser printer. ...a laser disc.

form.definition: noun Your lashes are your eyelashes. I put mascara on my lashes to make them thicker. 2a noun A lash is the strip of cord or leather at the end of a whip. In the early days of Australia, convicts were regularly punished with the lash.
noun A lash is a blow with a whip. He was sentenced to thirty lashes.

verb If someone lashes someone, they hit them with a whip. He was lashed to within an inch of his life for stealing. b verb If someone lashes someone or lashes into them, they criticise them very severely. Harry really lashed into Dieter for forgetting the appointment. The report lashes the government's handling of the situation.
verb If the weather lashes something, it hits it with great force. The coast was lashed by a tremendous storm. The rain was lashing at the window.

adjective If something is last, it is the one that comes after all the others in a group of things. The last question was the hardest. I missed the last bus. That's the last time I try to help her! Louise was last to finish. Who wants the last chocolate? Put this one last.
adjective If someone is last in a competition, exam or race, they do worse than everyone else. Juan came last in the 100 metres.

adjective If you say something is the last thing you expected or the last thing you needed, you mean you really didn't expect it or you absolutely didn't need it. He's the last person I'd have thought would succeed. A visit from Phil is the last thing I need right now.

adjective In some phrases, the last thing is the most recent before the present one. I went to the movies last night. We first met last year. We discussed this at our last meeting. The same thing happened last time. This book's better than her last one.
adverb If you do something last, you do it after everything else. I left the ironing till last. I buy imported goods last, only if there's no other choice. Use this one last.

adverb If something last happened at a particular time, it hasn't happened since then. I last met him six months ago. I've lost my glasses and can't remember where I had them last. It's ten years since I was last in Perth. 5a verb If something lasts for a certain length of time, it goes on for that amount of time. That is the amount of time it takes. The ceremony lasted for two hours. This cold seems to be lasting for ever.

b verb If something lasts for a certain length of time, it endures or survives for that amount of time. I hope our poor old cat can last another couple of years. Our car's lasted wellit's old, but still sound. The coffee should last till Friday. I've got $20 to last me the week.
6 at last If something happens at last, it finally happens after a long wait. At last we're together again! So you've got here at last! I looked everywhere and at last I found it under the bed.
7 the last (a) The last of something is the part or the one that remains to the end. Who wants the last of the soup? The last of my exams is on Friday.

(b) If you are the last to do something, you do it after everyone else. Louise was the last to finish. I must have been the last in the department to hear about it. ... WORD FAMILYadjective lasting It left a lasting impression on me. We need a lasting solution to the problem.[qr

dictionary.entry:
latchlAtS
noun A latch is a device that holds shut a door or a gate. It has a bar which you move into a certain position to keep the gate shut and which you lift to open it.
2 latch onto (a) If someone latches onto you, they become very keen to spend time in your company, although you find this rather irritating. Keiko latched onto me at the partyI couldn't get rid of her.
(b) If you latch onto something, you understand it or become aware of it. Rasha latched onto the problem very quickly.
... WORD FAMILYverb latch Be sure and latch the gate behind you, so the dog doesn't get out.

latelEIt(\minion0\adjectiveandadverbforms\optima0\laterlatest 1a adjective If someone or something is late, they arrive or happen after the time when they were expected. I was late for class. We'll start at threedon't be late! The baby's a week late already.
adverb If you do something late, you do it after the time when you were supposed to. I handed my essay in late. The buses are running late this morning.
adjective If something is late, it happens or continues after the usual time. We had a late lunch. I've been having too many late nights recently. There's a special late screening at the cinema on Friday night.
adverb If you do something late, you do it after the usual time. I get up late on Sundays.
adjective If something is described as late, it is towards the end of a period of time. We arrived in the late afternoon. I'll be back in late May. She's in her late thirties. This is one of the late twentieth century's major problems.
adverb If something happens late, it happens towards the end of a period of time. I love walking in the park late at night. He got up to speak quite late in the meeting.
adverb Late also means 'far into the night'. I stayed up late watching TV. The restaurant is open from seven till late. Look, it's late and we're all tired.
adjective In formal language, late describes someone who has died. My late husband was very fond of his pipe. The late Fred Hollows was famous as an eye surgeon.

form.definition: adverb Lately means 'recently'. I've been getting a lot of headaches lately. I haven't seen Joan latelyis she OK? I've only lately arrived in town.
adverb If something happens later, it happens after something else. At first I didn't like him, but later we became friends. Later I came to realise she was right.
adjective Later is the comparative form of late, and means 'more late'. She is always later than Marc.
adjective Latest is the superlative form of late, and means 'most late'. This is the latest he's ever been.

adjective The latest news or fashion is the most recent or up to date. The latest reports indicate that Labor is in the lead. He's got all the latest CDs. Is this the latest issue? Have you heard the latest? Corinne's split up with Guy.
noun Lather is the foam that you get when you rub something in water with soap or a detergent. This washing up liquid makes too much lather.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb lather Lather your hair, then rinse well.

form.definition: noun Latin is the language that was spoken by the ancient Romans.

adjective Someone is Latin if they come from the Mediterranean countries, especially southern France, Italy, Spain and Portugal, or from other countries connected with them. She has dark, Latin, good looks. ...Latin America.
noun Latitude is the position of a place north or south of the equator. It is measured in degrees. Camooweal is at latitude twenty degrees south.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with longitude.

form.definition: adjective In rather formal language, the latter thing is the second one of two things that have been mentioned. I much prefer the latter plan.

adjective In rather formal language, latter refers to the later or more recent part of a period of time. The project will go ahead in the latter half of next year. This has only become a problem in latter years.

In rather formal language, if two things or people are mentioned, you can subsequently refer to the second one as the latter. You can either withdraw your superannuation or reinvest it. It's probably better to do the latter.
noun A lattice is a frame made from strips of wood or metal crossing each other in a pattern of squares or diamonds. I've got a grape vine growing over a lattice in my garden.

verb If you laugh, you make a sound in your throat which shows that you are happy or that you think something is funny. People also sometimes laugh because they are nervous or to show scorn. She laughed with delight. The baby laughed when it saw me. The audience laughed at the clowns. Promise you won't laugh if I tell you? The other kids laughed at her accent.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun laugh He's got a very silly laugh. He gave a sarcastic laugh. adjective laughable The idea is so crazy that it's laughable.noun laughter We could hear the laughter of the audience.

form.definition: verb If someone launches a boat, they put it into the water. They launched a jet boat to rescue the fishermen. The new liner was launched by the premier's wife.
verb If someone launches a rocket, they send it up into the air. We launched distress flares to signal our position. The new satellite is due to be launched next month.
verb If someone launches a new product, they put it onto the market and hold a special promotion for it. We're going to launch the new range of clothes in June.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun launch The launch was delayed by bad weather. They gave the new model a big launch.

form.definition: noun A laundromat is a place with a lot of washing machines and driers where you can take your clothes to wash them if you don't have a washing machine at home.
noun A laundry is a small room in your house where you have a washing machine. The unit has an internal laundry.

noun A laundry is also a business or a department in an institution where clothes and other items are washed, dried and ironed. I sent my shirts to the hotel laundry. Rada works in the hospital laundry.
noun Laundry is clothes and other items that are ready to be washed or have just been washed. The dirty laundry goes in this basket. I was hanging the laundry out to dry.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb launder I sent my shirts to be laundered.

form.definition: noun A lavatory is a toilet.
noun Lavender is a small herbal plant with narrow leaves, pale bluish-purple flowers, and a strong sweet smell. Anything of that colour is said to be lavender in colour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective lavender The bridesmaids were dressed in lavender silk. ...lavender oil.

form.definition: adjective If you are lavish, you are very generous or extravagant. She was embarrassingly lavish with her gifts. This is a dessert where you can be lavish with the cream. He was lavish in his praise for our achievement.

adjective If something is lavish, it is large or luxurious. Henry's Christmas dinners are quite lavish. They live in a lavish apartment right in the city centre. 2 verb If you lavish something on someone, you give it to them in generous quantities. She lavishes attention on her grandchildren. Tasha lavished hours of work on the carving.

noun The law is the system of rules under which a society operates. It controls people's behaviour by stating what is not allowed and provides a system for those who do not obey to be tried and punished. Shoplifting is against the law. By law, all Australian citizens over 18 must vote in state and federal elections. The rule of law must be upheld.
noun A law is a rule made by a federal, state or local government to control people's behaviour. The laws governing unfair dismissal are complex. There ought to be a law against it!
noun The rules of some games are called laws. I don't know all the laws of cricket.
noun A scientific law is a statement about the way things are observed to work. Boyle's Law states that the pressure of a gas is inversely proportional to its volume.
noun Law is a subject of study concerned with the body of laws that exist and with legal practice. Judy's studying law at university. He's an expert in commercial law.
4 law court A law court is a place where disputes are decided (a civil court) or people are tried for crimes (a criminal court).
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See lawful. noun See lawyer. adjective See legal.

form.definition: adjective In formal language, if you say something is lawful, you mean that it is not against the law. You are allowed to do it. Such actions may be lawful, but they are utterly immoral. I was obstructed while going about my lawful business.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb lawfully You cannot lawfully refuse.

form.definition: noun A lawn is a patch of grass in a garden or park which is mown regularly and generally well looked after. Jim mows the lawn in front of his house every Sunday morning. There are vast expanses of lawn in the grounds of the university.
2 lawn cemetery A lawn cemetery is a place where people are buried in plots that form part of a large lawn.
noun A lawnmower is a machine you use to cut the grass and keep your lawns tidy. Most lawnmowers have a small motor to turn the cutting blades.

noun A lawyer is someone who is qualified in law and works as a solicitor or barrister. I want to have my lawyer look at the contract. The newspaper's lawyers suggested that the article could be libellous.

adjective If someone is lax, they are not careful about obeying rules or making sure that other people do so. Barry's far too lax about being on timehe's late at least two or three times a week. Standards had become lax under the former manager.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun laxity

form.definition: noun A laxative is a medicine which helps to relieve or prevent constipation. It softens the contents of the bowel and helps you to excrete faeces.
verb Lay is the past tense of the verb lie. (See lie, senses 1, 2 and 4.)
verb If you lay something somewhere, you place it there so that it is lying flat. She picked up the book and laid it on the table. We've just bought new carpetthey'll lay it for us next week.
verb To lay a table for a meal, you put things such as knives, forks, spoons and glasses on it. Lay the table, please, Dina. I laid an extra place in case he turned up.
verb When a hen produces an egg from its body, you say that it lays an egg. The hens are laying well this week.
verb If you lay plans, you plan something carefully or prepare a certain plan of action. We should be starting to lay plans for our holiday. She had laid a plot to bring about his downfall.
verb If you lay a bet, you gamble money on what you think will happen. I always lay a bet on the Melbourne Cup. I'll lay you $10 he doesn't succeed!
verb In informal and rather offensive language, if you say you lay someone, you mean you have sex with them. Tom had always wanted to lay Angela. When did you last get laid?
noun In informal and rather offensive language, if you say someone is a good lay or an easy lay, you mean that they are pleasant to have sex with or they will readily agree to have sex.
adjective A lay person is someone who is not a member of the clergy. The services are led by a lay preacher.
adjective A lay person is someone who is not a specialist in some technical field. These controversies are difficult for the lay person to follow.

9 laid up In informal language, if you say someone is laid up, you mean that they can't do their normal activities because they are sick or injured. I've been laid up in bed for five days. Half the department has been laid up with flu this week.

10 lay down If you lay something down, you specify or give firm instructions for it. The rules don't lay down what to do in this case. The coach has really laid down the law this timelights out by 10 pm.

11 lay off If someone is laid off from a job, they are dismissed, usually because there is no more work for them to do. The boss had to lay off six men last week. They laid him off with only two days' notice.

12 lay on If you lay something on, you arrange for it to be provided. They laid on special buses when the rail service was disrupted. Our hosts laid on a magnificent banquet for us. Every facility that you can imagine is laid on at the resort.
13 lay out (a) If you lay something out, you spread it out flat. She laid the cloth out on the table for us to see. The body is washed and laid out ready for the funeral.

(b) If you lay something out, you arrange its design. The house is laid out with one bedroom on each floor. Their garden is beautifully laid out. You should lay the report out with more space between the sections. (c) In informal language, if you say someone lays someone out, you mean that they knock them unconscious. Say that again and I'll lay you out! (d) In informal language, if you say you lay out money, you mean you spend it. We've laid out a lot of money on the project, and we want to see some return. I'm prepared to lay out $5000 for a good computer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See layout.[qr

form.definition: noun Lay-by is a way of buying something by paying for it over a period of time because you can't afford it at the beginning. The shop keeps the item until you've paid for it, and usually doesn't charge you any extra for doing it. Can I put this on lay-by?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb lay-by

form.definition: noun A layer is a thickness of some material laid over something. The doors were covered with several layers of paint. There was a layer of dust on the furniture.

The layout of something is the way it is designed and arranged. I like the layout of this houseit gives a very spacious effect. I learned about page layout as part of my graphics course. She sketched the layout of the circuits.
adjective If someone is lazy, they are reluctant to work hard or to do things that require energy. She's too lazy to even keep the house clean. Get up, you lazy slob!
adjective If you have a lazy time, you relax and take things easily. We spent a lazy day at the beach. I love those lazy Sundays when you can sleep in.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb laze Stop lazing around and get on with your work! I was lazing in the sun. noun laziness

form.definition: verb If you lead a group or procession, you are at the front of it, with other people or vehicles following behind you. The leading float was just passing the Town Hall.
verb If you lead a group of people or an activity, you are in charge. Ben leads our sales force. She may well lead the party into the next election. In Jason's absence, Scott led the meeting.
noun If you take the lead in doing something, you are the first person to do it. Our company took the lead in applying this technology to consumer products.

verb If you are leading in a competition or race, you are winning at that stage. At the halfway mark, Jenny was leading. Jones leads, three games to one. b noun The lead is the first position in a competition or race. Brooks is in the lead, with Tonelli close behind. France has taken the lead from Australia.

noun Your lead is the amount by which you are ahead of the next competitor. Jane had a good lead after the third lap. Indonesia has established a commanding lead. Cabretti's lead has been reduced to just over three seconds.
verb If you lead someone somewhere, you guide or accompany them there. He led us to the cave he'd found earlier. She led him down the stairs.

verb If something such as a path or road leads somewhere, it goes there. If you go along it, you get to that place. This road leads to the city centre. The steps lead down to the beach. The path led us around the back of the houses.

verb If something leads somewhere or leads you to do something, it guides or directs you naturally in that direction. Just where is this discussion leading? These discoveries led to some important changes. What first led you to study geology?
noun A lead in a crime case is a clue that may lead to its solution. Police are investigating a number of leads. In the absence of any new leads, the murder is likely to remain unsolved.

noun If you give a lead, you indicate what should be done by doing it first yourself. The charity has given a lead in helping victims of the disaster. Local authorities are looking to the state government for a lead.
noun The lead in a movie or play is the most important role. Quang was asked to play the lead in the school play.

noun A lead is a strap or chain that you attach to a dog's collar when you take it for a walk. Another word for this is leash. Dogs must be kept on the lead in this park. She let the dog off its lead.
noun Lead is also a soft grey metal. The church roof is covered in lead. The paint contains dangerously high levels of lead. The government has lowered the permitted level of lead in petrol.
noun The lead in a pencil is the centre part that makes the marks on the paper when you write.
11 lead off If you lead off, you start an activity going. The band led off the procession. Sarah led off the discussion with a suggestion about cutting costs. You should lead off on your right foot.

12 lead on If you lead someone on, you encourage them in a false belief so that they will continue to do what you want. The investigators led him on until he revealed further details of the scheme. He thought they would get married but she was only leading him on.

13 lead up to (a) If something leads up to something else, it comes before it and is often the cause of its happening. The days leading up to the election were tense. She gave an account of the events leading up to the shooting.
(b) If you lead up to a subject, you prepare the way before you begin to discuss it. I was just leading up to the subject of compensation. What is all this leading up to?
form.note: ... BE CAREFULwith the pronunciation of this word: the nouns given as senses 10 a and b have a different pronunciation from the rest. ... WORD FAMILYnoun See leader. adjective leading She is one of Australia's leading young artists.

form.definition: noun The leader of a group or activity is the person who is in charge. The team needs a strong leader. He was elected Leader of the Opposition.
noun The leader in a competition or race is the person who is winning at that stage. The leader so far is Rosa Smith.
noun The leader in a newspaper is an article expressing the opinion of the editor about a topic of debate. Another word for this is editorial.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun leadership The party prospered under his leadership.

form.definition: noun A leaf is one of the flat green parts of a plant. Deciduous trees lose their leaves in winter.
noun A leaf is also a sheet of paper in a book. Several leaves had been torn out of her diary.
noun A leaf is an extra part that can be added in the middle of a table to extend it. We'll need to put both leaves in the table to seat eight.

4 leaf through If you leaf through a book, you turn over its pages quickly because you are looking for something or just reading bits of it. I leafed through the file to find the invoice. She leafed through a magazine in the waiting room. 5 turn over a new leaf If you say that you are going to turn over a new leaf, you mean that you intend to start behaving in a better or more acceptable way. I decided to turn over a new leaf and give up smoking.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective leafy (leafier, leafiest) We sat in the leafy shade of the fig tree.

form.definition: noun A league is a group of people who have banded together to achieve some objective. This is a rather old-fashioned word that is used in the name of some organisations. They formed a league to oppose the legislation.
noun A league is an association of sports clubs who play in competition against each other. They're the top team in the league.

3 in league If you are in league with someone, you are working together with them, often secretly, to achieve some objective. is a popular code of football in Australia and New Zealand. He plays league, not rugby union.
form.note: ... SPECIAL USAGEA Leagues Club is a social club that is run by the supporters of a rugby league football team. It provides entertainment, and food, gambling and sports facilities.

form.definition: verb If something such as a pipe, bottle or roof leaks, it allows a liquid or gas to escape from it or pass through it.

verb If a liquid or gas leaks out of something or through something, it passes through small holes or cracks. 2a verb If someone leaks information, they reveal something that is supposed to be secret, usually to the press or other media.
verb If news leaks or leaks out, it becomes known.
3 take a leak In very informal language, if you say you take a leak, you mean you urinate. Joe's gone off to take a leak.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun leak There's a leak in the bucket. The area was evacuated because of a gas leak. noun leakage We must prevent the leakage of toxic chemicals into the soil.adjective leaky (leakier, leakiest) All I could find was a leaky old bucket.

form.definition: verb If you lean in a certain direction, you bend the top of your body so that it slopes that way. She leant forward to hear better. He leaned out of the window and threw the ball.

verb If you lean against something, you rest your body against it. He waited outside, leaning against the wall. I leaned the ladder against the tree and climbed up. She leant her head in her hands and sobbed. He hobbled in, leaning on a stick.
adjective If someone is lean, they are thin and usually athletic. Cyrus was a lean boy of sixteen. b adjective If meat is lean, it doesn't have much fat. They served me a beautifully lean steak.
3 lean towards If you lean towards an idea or plan, you tend to favour it. The committee leaned towards the second option.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun leaning Camilla has artistic leaningsshe spends most of her time painting.

form.definition: is one of the past tense forms of the verb lean.
verb If you leap, you jump, usually a long way or high in the air. She leapt across the creek. The horse leapt the hedge with ease.
verb If you leap somewhere, you move there quickly. He leapt up out of his chair when I came in. I leapt into a taxi and dashed over to the other side of town.
2 leap at If you leap at something, you accept it very eagerly. He leapt at the chance to go to the concert. Who wouldn't leap at a salary of $100 000 a year?
3 leap forward If something leaps forward, it makes a dramatic advance. Computer technology has leapt forward in the last ten years.
4 leap year A leap year is a year with 366 days in it, including February 29th. Every fourth year is a leap year.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun leap He took a leap across the creek. This discovery is a major leap forward.

form.definition: is one of the past tense forms of the verb leap.

verb If you learn a fact, you find out about it and remember it. I've got to learn this vocabulary for homework. We're learning about the digestive system in biology. We learnt that Dave had died six months ago.
verb If you learn a subject, you study it. You gradually find out all about it or how to do it well. I learnt Japanese at school. I've always wanted to learn the violin.

verb If you learn a quality or trait, you come to have it as part of your character. You're going to have to learn patience. Inner city children are often brought up in an atmosphere where they learn violence at an early age.
verb If you learn to do something, you acquire the ability to do it. All children should learn to swim. I learnt to read at the age of three.
verb If you learn to do something, you gradually manage it over a period of time. They used to fight but they've learned to live together peacefully. I've learned to accept my husband's death.
verb If you learn from an experience, you are wiser as a result of it. I learned a lot from watching the way he handled people. Some people never learn!

4 learn your lesson If you learn your lesson, you become wiser as the result of a bad experience. You will not make the same mistake again. I've learnt my lessonI'll back up computer files regularly in future. 5 learn something the hard way If you learn something the hard way, you become wiser as the result of a bad experience instead of taking someone's advice. He learnt the hard way not to show people his work.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun learner

form.definition: noun A lease is a legal agreement by which someone rents something such as a house from its owner for a fixed period of time in return for an agreed sum of money. I have a two-year lease on the property.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb lease We lease the premises from the council.

form.definition: noun A leash is a strap or chain which you attach to a dog's collar when you take it for a walk.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is lead.

form.definition: adverb Least indicates that something is true to the smallest extent. I don't like any of them much, but I like Doug least. None of them offered to help, least of all Susie. Those who can least afford it are being forced to pay more.
adverb Least indicates that the adjective it applies to is true to the smallest extent. I chose the least expensive model. It's not so much a question of which is the best as which is least bad.
adjective Least refers to the smallest amount of something. I chose the steak with the least fat on it.

pronoun Least means the smallest amount. When she served out the soup I got least. Marla did least of all to help. I'll drive you home; it's the least I can do after all your help. It's a mess to say the least.

3 at least (a) You use at least to show that what you mention is the minimum. There were at least two hundred people there. At least 50% of members must vote for the change. He must weigh 200 kilos at the absolute least. She could at least have thanked us. (b) You use at least to qualify what you've just said. Bill's twentyat least I think he is. Valda's coming at eight o'clock, or at least that's what she told me.
(c) You use at least to point out a good aspect of a bad situation. He's still very sick but at least he's getting better.
noun Leather is the skin of animals, particularly cattle, which has been specially treated. It is used to make things such as shoes, bags, belts and chairs.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective leather ...a leather belt. ...a leather sofa.

form.definition: verb If you leave, you go away or depart. We need to leave at six. He left for the airport an hour ago. I'm just leaving the office. I don't like to leave my son when he's sick. He left his wife for another woman.

verb If you leave somewhere such as a school, university or job, you stop going there. Ute leaves school next year. He left his job to travel round the world. She left the organisation in protest at its policies.
verb If you leave something somewhere, you put it there. If you're not in the office, I'll leave the report on your desk. The detergent has left stains on the cutlery.
verb If you leave something somewhere, you forget to take it with you when you go. I left my watch on the piano. Oh no! I've left my glasses at home.

verb If you leave something, you don't deal with it. He left the washing-up until the following day. If you can't solve the problem now, leave it and come back to it when you're fresh. If you can't eat all the food, just leave it.
If you leave something in a certain condition, you allow it to remain like that. The artist left the painting unfinished. Please leave me alone. Why can't you all leave me in peace?

verb If you leave something to someone or leave someone to do something, you allow them to do it without interfering. Can I leave the arrangements for the party to you? I set the problem and left them to work it out.
verb If you leave something to someone, you bequeath it to them so that they inherit it when you die. My mother left me the cottage in her will. Their father left them nothing but debts.

noun Leave is absence from work that you are officially entitled to. I get four weeks annual leave. Michelle's on leave at the moment. I took a day's leave to help my friend move house. Rajir was granted a week's compassionate leave.

noun A lecture is a talk that gives information about a subject, often as part of a conference or a course of study. The new professor gave a public lecture. Tamsin's been missing a lot of lectures lately.
noun A lecture is a talk that tells someone how to behave. The boss gave us another lecture about being on time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb lecture He lectures in history. Don't lecture me about my smoking!noun lecturer She's a lecturer at the uni.

form.definition: verb Led is the past tense form of the verb lead.[qr

dictionary.entry:
ledgelEdZ
noun A ledge is a narrow shelf which sticks out from the side of something. The climbers were huddled on a ledge on the side of the mountain. A bird settled on the window ledge.

form.definition: noun A ledger is a book in which accounts are kept. It is a record of all the money that comes in and is paid out.
verb If someone leers at you, they smile at you in an unpleasant way which makes you feel very uncomfortable. I could see him leering at me through the window.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun leer

form.definition: verb Left is the past tense and past participle of leave.
adjective The left side of something is the opposite side to the right. When you face north, the west is on your left side. He wore a ring on his left hand.
noun The left is the left side. In Australia we drive on the left. English is written from left to right.
noun The left is a political philosophy or grouping which tends towards socialism. These moves have angered the left.
adjective If someone is left-handed, they prefer to use their left hand for writing, eating and other basic tasks.
noun Your legs are your lower limbs. He was standing on one leg. A spider has eight legs.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body. b noun The legs of a pair of trousers or overalls are the parts that cover your legs.

form.definition: noun The[qrlegs of a chair or table are the parts that support it by resting on the floor.
noun A leg of a long journey or race is one part of it. The third leg of the car rally took us across the desert.

4 have a leg to stand on If you say that someone doesn't have a leg to stand on, you mean that there is no justification for what they claim or have done. When I produced the receipts he didn't have a leg to stand on. She claimed that it had been the best decision at the time, but really she didn't have a leg to stand on.

5 pull someone's leg If you pull someone's leg, you tease them or tell them something which is not true, as a joke. He was always pulling her leg about her popularity with the boss. That can't be truethey're pulling your leg!
adjective If something is legal, it is allowed by law. Is it legal to park here? His blood alcohol level was way above the legal limit.
adjective Legal means relating to the law. I sought legal advice about my rights. Mirka's a legal secretary.
3 legal aid If you are granted legal aid, you get financial help from the government to pay for a lawyer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun legality (legalities) I doubt the legality of their action. We need to look into the legalities.verb legalise (or legalize) They are calling for euthanasia to be legalised.adverb legally You cannot legally do that.

form.definition: noun A legend is a very old story, which may be based on real people and events, and which has been passed down from one generation to the next. I love reading myths and legends from around the world.
noun If you call someone a legend, you mean that their achievements are so outstanding that they are remembered for a long time. Don Bradman is one of Australia's greatest cricket legends.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective legendary

dictionary.entry: leggings`lEgINz <plural noun Leggings are women's tight trousers made from light, stretchy material.

form.definition: adjective If something is legible, you can read it. The address was barely legible.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is illegible.

form.definition: noun Legislation is laws that are made by a government about a particular issue. The government passed new legislation on tax evasion. They promised to introduce legislation into the next parliament.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb legislate

form.definition: adjective If something is legitimate, it is appropriate and acceptable. His claim to the money is legitimate. There can be no legitimate argument in favour of this policy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun legitimacy

form.definition: noun Leisure is the time when you are not working. You can relax and do what you want. Quan doesn't have much leisure.
2 at leisure If you tell someone to do something at their leisure, you mean that they can do it when it's convenient. It is not urgent. It might be worth redrawing the diagrams, at your leisure.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective leisure What are your main leisure activities?

form.definition: noun A lemon is a yellow citrus fruit with a sour taste. The fish was garnished with a slice of lemon.
noun Lemon is a bright yellow colour. We chose lemon for the kids' bedroom.
noun In informal language, if you call something a lemon, you mean it doesn't work as it should. It is a disappointment to you. I shouldn't have trusted that car dealerhe's sold me a lemon.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective lemon She was wearing a lemon sun dress.adjective lemony The cake has a pleasant lemony taste.

form.definition: noun Lemonade is a soft drink, usually fizzy, made from lemons or flavoured to taste like lemons.

verb If you lend something to someone, you allow them to have it for a short time, but you expect them to give it back to you. She lent me her book to read. Could you lend me $20 till the end of the week?
verb If a bank lends you money, it lets you have the money for a period of time, but you have to pay interest on it as well as repay the original sum.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is borrow. ... WORD FAMILYnoun See loan.

form.definition: noun The length of something is its size from one end to the other. What is the length of the tape measure? The snake was over two metres in length. He stretched out at full length on the grass.
noun The length of something is the amount of time it takes. The main problem with the movie is its lengthit drags on for four hours. What is the length of the flight?

noun A length of something such as rope, fabric or wood is a long piece of it that can be used for a specific purpose. I bought a length of material to make a dress. The two lengths of wood have been screwed together.
noun If you swim a length, you swim from one end of a pool to the other. I try to do ten lengths every day.
4 at length (a) If you do something at length (such as talk or write), you do it in great detail so that it takes a long time. He presented his findings at length.
(b) If something happens at length, it finally happens, after a long time. At length they replied to our letter.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See long.

form.definition: verb If you lengthen something or it lengthens, it becomes longer from one end to the other. I've made the dress with a deep hem so I can lengthen it as Becky grows. By noon the queue had lengthened to nearly two hundred people.

verb If you lengthen something or it lengthens, it becomes longer in the time it takes. Let's not lengthen the process by going into so much detail. The days are lengthening now that we're into October.
adjective If someone is lenient, they are not harsh in punishing people. Often they let them get off too lightly. This time I'm prepared to be lenient, but it mustn't happen again.

noun A lens is a piece of transparent glass or plastic with a curved surface. Lenses can make things look bigger or smaller, and are used in cameras, and to correct poor eyesight. The lenses of my glasses are very scratched. I have to leave my contact lenses to soak overnight.
verb Lent is the past tense and past participle of lend.
noun A leotard is a tight-fitting piece of clothing you wear when you are dancing or exercising. It looks like a one-piece swimsuit, but it often has arms.
noun A lesbian is a woman who is sexually attracted to other women.

adverb Less indicates that something is true to a smaller extent. I smoke less these daysI've almost stopped altogether. The more I see of her, the less I like her. I like Chinese food far less than Thai. It hurt less than I expected.

adverb Less indicates that an adjective applies to a smaller extent. My job is far less important to me than my family. It's far less humid today, thank goodness. I'd like to see something a bit less expensive. Please try and be less noisy.

adjective Less refers to a smaller amount of something. To refer to a smaller number of things that you can count individually, you should use fewer. You need to use a bit less pressure. I had less difficulty than before. b pronoun Less means a smaller amount. I can't eat all that. Could you give me a bit less, please? The appeal raised less than $2000.
preposition In arithmetic, less means minus. Ten less two is eight. We made $400, less $90 expenses.

verb If you lessen something or it lessens, it becomes less or smaller in amount or severity. Our funds are rapidly lessening. These tablets should lessen the pain. We've made arrangements to lessen the disruption.

noun A lesson is a short period of time when you learn about something. Normally you do a sequence of lessons to make up a course of study. I'm taking cooking lessons. There are no lessons on Friday afternoons.
noun A lesson is something that you learn from experience. Let this be a lesson to you! From her, I learnt the lesson that it's worth being patient.

verb If you let something happen, you allow it to happen. You don't try to prevent it from happening. I let the ball bounce twice before hitting it. Let the dye soak in thoroughly. Don't let the dogs fight. You shouldn't let the card get wet. She let the matter pass.
verb If you let someone do something, you give them your permission to do it. She let him drive her car. I don't let my daughter stay out all night. Why don't you let me do that? You must be tired.

verb If you let someone or something in, out, up or down, you allow them to move there. The cat was scratching at the door to be let in. He let the air out of the balloon. She let the basket down on a rope. He pinned me on my back and wouldn't let me up.

verb If you let a unit[qr[qror shop to someone, you allow them to use it in return for rent. I'm afraid that property is already let. 3 let down If someone lets you down, they disappoint you by not doing what they promised. He's let me down beforewhy should I trust him now? I'm sorry to let you down, but I just can't make it today.

4 let go If you let something go or let go of something, you stop holding it, so that it falls or escapes. Once in the park you can let the dog go. I let the balloon go and it floated away. Don't let go of the bucket. It can be hard to let go of these emotions. Let go! Leave me alone!

5 let know If you let someone know about something, you inform them of it. You tell them about it. Let me know what happens, please. I'll let you know as soon as I hear anything. Have a look and let me know what you think. Be sure and let me know in advance if you can't come. 6 let off (a) If you let someone off, you don't punish them or make them do something. I was just over the speed limit and the police officer let me off with a warning. You've got a lot of studying to doso I'll let you off the washing up tonight.
(b) If you let something off, you cause it to explode. They let the fireworks off at 8 p.m. so the kids could stay up and see them. The sentry let off a warning shot.
7 let on If you let on, you reveal your knowledge about something secret. Don't let on to Lena about the surprise party. I didn't let on that I already knew. He's more involved than he lets on.
8 let's You use let's in making suggestions. Let's go to the movies. Let's give Lara a chance. Let's not be discouraged. Don't let's tell Andrew about it.

9 let up If something lets up, it gets less in intensity or it stops. The rain seems to be letting up now. The kids are absolutely exhaustingthey just never let up. The workload should let up a bit in January.

adjective If something is lethal, it is so dangerous or harmful that it can cause death. Guns are lethal weapons and you must be careful in handling them. The lethal dose is less than 5 mg. This poison is lethal to small animals.

noun A letter is a written message which you send to someone, usually by post in an envelope with their name and address on it. Were there any letters for me in the mail today? I'm writing a letter to my sister. The magazine publishes letters from readers.

noun A letter is a symbol which is used in writing. Many languages, including English, use an alphabet of letters to provide a writing system. She wrote her name in large letters. Is this letter an M or an N? You have to choose a password of up to eight letters or numbers.
noun Leukaemia is a cancer of the blood cells. It is a very serious disease and in adults usually causes death.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is leukemia.

form.definition: adjective If something is level, it is even or flat. No part of it is higher than the rest. Make sure the floor is completely level before you lay the tiles. 'Is this picture level?' 'No, move the right side down a bit.'

adjective If something is level with something else, it is equal with it. Neither one is ahead of or behind the other. The two runners were level as they came into the final bend. The unions argue that salary increases should keep level with inflation.

noun The level of something is a measure of how high up or how far above something else it is. Fill the jug to the one-litre level. Mt Kosciusko is more than 2000 m above sea level. The water will find its own level. This plaque shows the level that the flood reached. b noun The level of something is a measure of its amount or quantity. The level of interest in the offer has been disappointing. Sinit shows a high level of talent. You need to monitor your blood sugar level. c noun If you are at a certain level in your education or job, you have advanced to that standard or ranking. We run one course for beginners, and another at a more advanced level. Share options are available to employees at deputy manager level and above.

3 on the level In informal language, if you say that someone is on the level, you mean that they are being honest or telling the truth. Do you think he's on the level? I suspect the company's not altogether on the level. No, really, on the level, I'll pay you next week.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb level (levels, levelled, levelling) We used a tractor to level the ground.

form.definition: noun A lever is a long piece of wood or metal that you use to lift something. You can raise a heavy weight with little force if the pivot is very close to the end where the weight is.
noun A lever is a bar or handle on a piece of machinery which you push or pull in order to start or control it. Pull this lever to get the lawnmower started. I reached down for the gear lever.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb lever I levered the rock out of the way with an iron bar.

form.definition: noun A levy is a sum of money that you have to pay as a tax or fee. We pay an environmental levy on our water bill.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb levy (levies, levied, levying) The government has the power to levy taxes.

form.definition: noun Your liability is the extent to which you are legally responsible for something. The owners of the car refused to accept liability for the accident. The liability of shareholders is limited to the amount of their investment.

noun If you say that someone or something is a liability, you mean that they cause a lot of trouble and are a disadvantage to you. Joe's so clumsyhe's a real liability on our team. Too much luggage can be a liability when you're travelling.
3 liabilities Your liabilities are your debts and amounts that you're bound to pay in future. The opposite of this is assets.
adjective If you are liable for something, you are legally responsible for it. If you guarantee the loan, you are liable for the full amount of the debt. If anything goes wrong I'll hold you liable.

adjective If someone is liable to do something, they have a tendency to do it. They often do it. Mavis is liable to lose her temper when things go wrong. The desserts they serve are liable to be quite rich.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun liable

form.definition: noun Liaison is communication and cooperation between people or organisations. The project requires close liaison between the different departments.
noun Liaison is a rather old-fashioned word for a sexual relationship, especially a secret one. Few people were aware of their liaison.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb liaise Can you liaise with Daniel to arrange a meeting time?

form.definition: noun A liar is someone who tells lies. Liar! You know that's not true! Are you calling me a liar? Billy's a terrible liarhe makes up the most amazing stories.
noun Libel is written remarks that are likely to damage someone's reputation.
form.note: ... A SIMILAR WORDis slander, spoken words likely to damage someone. Both libel and slander are forms of defamation. ... WORD FAMILYadjective libellous

form.definition: adjective If someone is liberal, they are tolerant or broadminded. I take a liberal attitude to other people's beliefs. You would probably be accepted if they use a liberal interpretation of the rules.

adjective If someone is liberal, they are generous. He was liberal in his compliments. You need to be fairly liberal with the glue to get it to stick properly. She passed me a liberal serving of dessert>.
adjective In Australian politics, Liberal refers to the Liberal Party of Australia. I've always been a Liberal voter. What is Liberal policy on the issue? She stood as a Liberal candidate.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb liberally Her face was liberally smeared with chocolate icing.

dictionary.entry:
Liberal Party of Australia /\times,0\lbrl pati v
noun The Liberal Party of Australia is one of the major Australian political parties.
... A SHORT FORMfor this is Liberal Party.

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you say you liberate someone, you mean that you set them free from captivity or especially from oppression. Protesters liberated dozens of laboratory animals. Troops stormed the plane and liberated the hostages. The rebels aim to liberate the masses. I felt liberated by the experience.
verb If you liberate someone or something, you set them free from whatever has been holding them back.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun liberation

form.definition: noun Liberty is freedom from imprisonment. She has served her sentence and deserves her liberty. I gave the bird its liberty. Liberty is a basic human right. 2 noun Liberty is being free to do as you please. When he got married he felt he lost his liberty. I've got quite a lot of liberty in the way I do my job.
3 at liberty In formal language, if you say that someone is at liberty to do something, you mean that they may do it if they wish. If he doesn't like it, he's quite at liberty to resign.

noun A library is a room or building where there is a large collection of books and journals. People can go there to read the books and sometimes they can also borrow them for a certain period. I got this novel from the public library. Tessa's studying in the library. How can I join the library? ...a tape library. ...a toy library.
noun A library is also a private collection of things such as books, CDs or computer software. He's got a vast library of early jazz recordings.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun librarian He works as a librarian at the university.

form.definition: <noun Lice is the plural form of louse.
noun A licence is an official document which shows that you have the right to do something. I need to renew my driver's licence. Do I need to get an export licence?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb license The police will have to license all gun owners from next year.

form.definition: verb If you lick something, you rub your tongue on it in order to wet it, or as a way of eating it. She licked the stamp and stuck it to the envelope. The boy was licking an ice-cream cone. The dog licked my face. ... WORD FAMILYnoun lick Can I have a lick of your ice block?
noun Licorice is a sweet spice which is obtained from the root of a plant. It is used to make sweets and some medicines.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is liquorice.[qr

dictionary.entry:
lidlId
noun A lid is a cover for a container. Put the lid on the saucepan and leave it to simmer. I can't get the lid off this tin.

liela:Ilies, lay, lain, lying for meanings 1, 2 and 4; lies, lied, lying for meaning
verb If you lie somewhere or lie down, you lower your body and stretch out so that you are in a horizontal position. He sauntered in and lay on the sofa. You must be tiredwhy don't you lie down for a bit? b verb If you lie somewhere, you stay there with your body in a horizontal position. He lay on the sofa watching television. I lay awake all night. It breaks my heart to see her lying in hospital. Are you going to lie in bed all morning? 2a verb If something lies somewhere, it is situated there in a horizontal position. The books were lying on the table. Her coat lay on the bed. Rich tapestries lay on the floor. Don't leave your toys lying around. The body lay unburied for a week. b verb If something lies somewhere, it is situated there. That is where it can be found. Wollongong lies 70 km south of Sydney. The truth lies somewhere between the two extremes.
verb If you lie, you say things that you know are untrue. Adrian lies all the time, so don't believe anything he says. Don't lie to meI know where you were. She lied to the committee about her involvement. b noun A lie is a statement you make which you know is untrue. Adrian tells lies all the time.
4 lie low If you lie low, you keep out of sight or don't draw attention to yourself because you are trying not to be noticed. He lay low for a few days until the journalists lost interest.

form.definition: noun Life is the state of being alive. It's an emergencya matter of life or death! At what point does life begin?
noun You can use life to refer to living things in general. There was life all around us in the forest. Is there life on other planets?

noun Your life is your existence as a living being. His life is in danger. Several lives were lost. She saved my life. 2a noun Your life is all the time that you are alive, from your birth till your death, and what you do in that time. She had a long life. I've tried to live a good life. I've remembered it all my life. I've never seen anything like it in my life! He began his working life as a clerk.
noun Your life is also what you experience while you are alive. They have an easy life. I got a taste for the good life. This is the life! Such is life! Life is full of disappointments.

noun If someone has a lot of life, they are very active and vigorous. Sally's got so much lifeI just can't keep up with her. I may be over eighty but there's plenty of life in me yet. Sing it again, and try to give it some life!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See live. adjective lifeless He lay lifeless on the sand. The characterisation is very lifeless.

form.definition: adjective If something is lifelong, you have it or experience it for a long period in your life. Maurice has been a lifelong friend to me. At last I fulfilled my lifelong ambition.

noun A lifesaver is a person who looks after people's safety at the beach. Lifesavers make sure that people swim between the red and yellow flags, and they rescue swimmers if they get into difficulty.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun lifesaving All pool attendants must be fully trained in lifesaving.

form.definition: noun Your lifetime is the length of time that you are alive. I've seen many changes in my lifetime. That won't happen within our lifetime. These saucepans should last you a lifetime.

verb If you lift something, you move it upwards. You raise it. He lifted his glass and smiled. I could hardly lift the case. We'll have to lift the floorboards. She lifted the vase down from the shelf. The crane lifted the statue in the air.
noun A lift is a small moving compartment in which you can go up and down between the floors of a tall building. Another word for this is elevator. I took the lift to the eighth floor.

noun If you give someone a lift, you drive them in your car to where they need to go, as a favour. I gave Tricia a lift home. Can I give you a lift anywhere? Maybe you'll be able to get a lift from someone else at the party.

noun Light allows us to see. Natural light comes from the sun; at night we use artificial light from lamps. The glass splits the ray of light into a spectrum. We sat in the flickering red light of the fire. Everything was bathed in a green light. The light's beginning to fade.

noun A light is a device that produces light, and which allows us to see or which acts as a signal. I turned on the bathroom light. This light comes on when the fuel is getting low. The children can't sleep without a light in the room. He was attracted by the bright city lights.

adjective If a place is light, it is easy to see things in it because there is plenty of light or illumination. The opposite of this is dark. What time does it get light? She's got a lovely light studio to work in.

adjective If something is light, it is pale in colour. The opposite of this is dark. That's a nice colour, but I want something a bit lighter. I chose one that was light green. She was wearing a light blue dress.

adjective If something is light, it doesn't weigh much. The opposite of this is heavy. Your suitcase is lightit must be nearly empty. I make a point of travelling light. I chose a light fabric for the dress.

adjective If something is light, it is not solid or strong or heavy. There is not much of it. They served us a light meal. This souffle is beautifully light and fluffy. There was a light breeze blowing. My workload is fairly light at the moment.
adjective If a book or a speech is light, it is not very serious. Detective stories are good light reading. She entertained us with some light stories about her travels.

verb If you light a place or an object, you shine a light in it or on it. The street is poorly lit at nightit's very unsafe. The room was lit with candles. The photographer lit the vase from below to emphasise its outline.

verb If you light something, you cause it to burn. He lit a cigarette. The power's failedwe'll have to light the candles. She piled the paper in the grate and lit it. You're not allowed to light fires here.

9 in the light of If you decide something in the light of certain information, you take those facts into consideration. In the light of the stock market crash, it seems wiser to invest in real estate.
10 throw light on If something throws light on something else, it provides new information which makes it easier to understand. His version of the story has thrown new light on the situation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb lighten I took out the shoes to lighten my case. I want something to lighten my hair. noun lighting The street lighting is very poor. He's studying stage lighting. noun lightness I love the lightness of this room. One feature of this model is its lightness.[qr

dictionary.entry: lightning`la:ItnIN noun Lightning is sudden flashes of light in the sky during a storm. Each flash of lightning is followed by a clap of thunder; the length of time between them tells you how far away the storm is.

form.definition: preposition If something is like something else, it is similar to it, or it resembles it. It is the same in some way. Her writing is quite like mine. Andrew's like Seanhe loves computers and music. That cloud looks a bit like a bear.

preposition If you ask someone what something is like, you are asking them to describe it. What's your house like? What does he look like? What was the weather like yesterday? What was it like to hear that you'd won the lottery?
preposition You can use like to make a comparison between two things. He eats like a pig. I've been working like a slave all day. I ran like the wind to get away.
preposition You can use like to point out that people have the same experience. Lucia comes from Italy like me. Like me, Peter had a lot of difficulty with the program.
verb If you like someone, you are fond of them. You enjoy being with them. I like Brendanhe's a nice guy. None of us likes the new manager.

verb If you like something, you find it enjoyable or acceptable. Do you like Thai food? I like walking in the park. What would you like to eat? Would you like another coffee? We'll go now, if you like. I don't like to disturb him.
verb If you ask someone how they like something, you are asking their opinion of it. How do you like Australia?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective likeable She's a likeable little girl. verb liken He likened himself to a Tasmanian devilsmall but fierce! noun likeness The picture was a good likeness.noun liking I have a liking for dark chocolate.

dictionary.entry:
likely`la:Ikli:likelierlikeliest 1a adjective If something is likely, it is probable. You think that it will happen or it is true. The likely outcome is that she'll resign. That's the most likely explanation. It's not likely that he'll pay up. b adjective If someone is likely to do something, they will probably do it. They're likely to be back soon, now it's getting dark. Do you think it's likely
2 a likely story If someone says that something is a likely story, they are being sarcastic. They mean that they do not believe an excuse or explanation that someone has given. 'He said his mother's sick.' 'A likely storyhe just wants a day off.'
3 most likely Most likely means 'probably'. Note that likely is not used on its own in this way. He'll come on Tuesday, most likely. That's most likely true.
4 not likely In informal language, if you say not likely, you are emphatically saying 'no'. 'Are you friends with Fred again?' 'Not likely.'

form.definition: noun Your limbs are your arms and your legs.
noun A limb of a tree is any of the larger branches.
noun A lime is a small green citrus fruit with a rather sour taste. The drink was served with a wedge of lime.
noun Lime is a bright yellow-green colour.
noun Lime is a white powder made by heating limestone. It is used in cement and for painting walls.
noun Lime is a chemical which you spread on soil to improve its quality.

noun If someone is in the limelight, they are getting a lot of attention and publicity. She loves being in the limelight. He has been in the limelight lately because he argued with the Prime Minister on TV.
noun Limestone is a soft white chalky rock.

noun The limit of something is its maximum extent. It is as far as it is able or allowed to go. That course is full to the limitwe can't accept any more students. The speed limit here is 60 km/h. I set myself a limit of three drinks a day. 2 noun The limit of an area is its boundary. We drove to the northern limits of her property.

verb If you limit something, you set an amount or level beyond which you do not allow it to go. The boss has limited to $50 the amount we can claim as petty cash. We need to limit spending to essentials as we're well over budget. Please try to limit the volume of photocopying.

verb If someone limits you, they place certain restrictions on what you can do or have. Passengers are limited to a single item of carry-on luggage. I limited myself to a small portion of cake. His condition limits him a lot, but he finds a way around most difficulties. 4 off limits If something is off limits, you are not allowed to go there. For this week, the river is off limits to all of youit's dangerous after the heavy rain.

5 the limit In informal language, if you say that someone or something is the limit, you mean that you are very annoyed or exasperated with them. That boy is the absolute limithe just won't do as he's told. Right, that's the limit, I won't put up with this! It really was the limit when she said we'd have to start again.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun limitation The program has certain limitations. We all have to accept our limitations. adjective limited We have a very limited budget. I have limited sympathy for him.adjective limiting I found the format of the course very limiting.

form.definition: noun A limited company is owned by shareholders, of whom there must be a minimum number. If the company goes bankrupt, the shareholders are liable for its debts only to the extent of their investment.
form.note: ... ANOTHER TERMfor this is limited-liability company.

form.definition: adjective If something is limp, it is soft and floppy. It is not rigid. It does not have the strength to support itself in an upright position. The flowers have all gone limp in the heat.
verb If you limp, you walk in a jerky way because there is something wrong with one of your legs. He was limping badly for two weeks after the accident.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun limp He walks with a limp.adverb limply The flag hung limply in the still air.

form.definition: noun A line is a long narrow mark on a surface. He drew a line under his surname. The ball has to land behind this line. A straight line is the shortest distance between two points. The snail traced a wiggly line on the rock.

noun A line is a group of things next to each other in a row or column. There's a line of tall trees beside the road. I looked for a break in the line of cars. The children were told to get into a line.
