noun A line of writing is one group of words which are written next to each other. The next line is written below them. Classified advertisements are charged at $5 per line. I wrote a few lines to thank her for the present. I can only remember the first two lines of the poem.

noun A line is also a long piece of rope, string or wire. I hung the clothes out on the line. The fisherman had got his line tangled. The storm brought down the power lines. You can call me through the switchboard or on my direct line.[ql5 noun A line is a railway track. The railway line runs parallel to the road. Lakemba is on the Bankstown line.
noun If you have lines on your face or body, you have wrinkles. She had fine lines all over her face.

noun A line is a particular product that a company sells. That's our best-selling line. We're introducing some new lines next month. 8 noun If you are in a certain line of business, that is your occupation. 'What's your line?' 'I'm in computers.' We decided to move into a new line of business. My particular line is applying technology to educational resources.

verb If you line something, you put a layer of something inside it, to protect it or insulate it or make it stronger or more attractive. He lined the dish with greaseproof paper. The jacket is lined with silk.
verb If things line a place, they are there along the edges. The crowds lined the streets to see the Pope. The room was lined with bookcases.
11 lined (a) If something is lined, it has lines marked on it. I bought a pad of lined writing paper. Her face was heavily lined.
(b) If a garment is lined, it has a lining. This skirt is fully lined.
12 line up (a) If you line up, you form a line. She got the children to line up for assembly. The prisoners were lined up against a wall and shot.
(b) If you line things up, you put them into the correct position in relation to each other. You need to line up the edges carefully before you stick them down.

(c) If you line up activities, you arrange them for the future. Apparently they've got some sort of entertainment lined up for us this evening. I can't go away nowI've got a lot lined up in the next few days.

13 out of line If you say someone is out of line, you mean that they have said or done something that you find unacceptable. He's way out of line, criticising her like that. We're all a few minutes late sometimes, but a whole hour is out of line.
noun Linen is a fabric made from the fibres of the flax plant. Linen is attractive, but it crumples so easily.
noun Linen is household items such as sheets, pillowcases and tablecloths.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective linen ...a linen suit. ...a linen cupboard.

form.definition: noun A liner is a disposable layer which you put inside something to protect it from being soiled. ...a bin liner. ...a nappy liner.
noun A liner is a large ship which carries passengers.
verb If you linger somewhere, you stay for longer than usual or when you really ought to go. I lingered at the bookstall and nearly missed my train.
verb If something such as a smell or a memory lingers, it stays around and doesn't immediately go away. The smell of fried onions does tend to linger; it gets into your clothes and hair!
noun Lingerie is a formal word used in stores to refer to women's underwear and night clothes.
adjective Linguistic means relating to language. Suk has great linguistic ability. 2 linguistics If you study linguistics, you study the way language works. I took a course in linguistics.
noun Liniment is an oily liquid that you can rub into your skin if you have bruises, sore muscles or sprained joints.

A lining is a layer of something inside something else, to protect it or insulate it or make it stronger or more attractive. Aspirin can damage the stomach lining, but they say it can prevent heart attacks. The coat has a detachable lining.
noun A link in a chain is one of the metal rings which it is made up of.

noun A link is anything that joins two things or forms a relationship between them. They are building a rail link to the airport. We have built strong links with our partners. Is there a causal link between the two? He broke all links with his family.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb link We linked arms. Her health problems are linked to her poor diet.

form.definition: noun Linoleum is a type of tough, waterproof floor covering that is used especially in kitchens, bathrooms and hallways.
form.note: ... A SHORT FORMof this is lino.

form.definition: noun Linseed oil is the oil which comes from the seeds of the flax plant. It is used to protect wood and to make paint and ink.
noun Your lips are the dark areas of skin at the outer edges of your mouth.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body. 2 bite your lip If you bite your lip, you try not to show your anger or pain.

form.definition: 3 lip service If you pay lip service to something, you support it in your words but not in your actions. They pay lip service to notions of equality, but they don't do much to promote women.
noun Lipstick is a coloured coating (or a stick of it) that some women put on their lips as a beauty aid. She was wearing lipstick. I bought a new lipstick, but that kind of red doesn't suit me.
verb If you liquefy something, especially a gas, you make it turn into a liquid form. Next we'll cool the oxygen until it liquefies. ...liquefied petroleum gas.
noun A liqueur is a strong, sweet alcoholic drink which people sometimes have after a meal. The banquet was rounded off with coffee and liqueurs. ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with liquor.
noun A liquid is any substance like water that can be poured. Mercury is a liquid at room temperature. What's this liquid in the bottom of the pan?
If your assets are liquid, they are in the form of cash or can easily be converted into cash. It's important to keep part of your portfolio liquid in order to cope with unexpected events.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See liquidate.

form.definition: verb If you liquidate a company that has large debts or is bankrupt, you sell its assets in order to pay outstanding debts. 2 verb In informal language, if you say that a gangster liquidates an opponent, you mean that they have them killed.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun liquidation The company is in liquidation.noun liquidator The company is in the hands of the liquidator.

form.definition: noun Liquor is a formal or official word for any alcoholic drink. You are not allowed to consume liquor on the premises. In Australia, people under 18 can't buy liquor.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis word with liqueur.

form.definition: verb If you lisp, you pronounce your s and z sounds as th.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun lisp She speaks with a lisp.

form.definition: noun A list is a set of words or phrases that you write down one below the other, often to help you remember. Are eggs on your shopping list? Who's drawing up the guest list for the party? I've got a whole list of things to do. Our tutor gave us a long reading list.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb list Are you listed in the phone book? How many native animals can you list?

form.definition: verb If you listen, you pay careful attention to something that you can hear. I love listening to music. Do you ever listen to the radio? Listen! Can you hear that creaking? She was listening for the baby's cries. Listen to this: 'Premier admits liability.'

verb If you listen to what someone says, you take notice of it and are influenced by it. He just won't listen to advice. Young people seldom listen to their parents. Listen! I've had just about enough of this behaviour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun listener

form.definition: adjective If you are listless, you have very little energy and you find it hard to do anything. This humid weather makes me listless. The dog was listless and off its food.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun listlessness

form.definition: verb Lit is the past tense and past participle of light.

adjective The literal meaning of something is its most basic or main meaning. She jokingly said she was a 100 years old and he took this as literal. Her translation was very literal and sounded quite unnatural.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb literally We received literally thousands of applications.

form.definition: adjective If you say that something is literary, you mean that it has to do with literature or fine writing. Let's make this sentence a bit plainer and less literary. I'd like to meet some of your literary friends.
adjective If someone is literate, they have learned how to read and write. The opposite of this is illiterate.
adjective If someone is literate in a particular subject or skill, they are educated or trained in it. All children today need to be computer literate.
adjective If someone is literate, they are cultured and educated. I was delighted to address such a literate audience.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun literacy

form.definition: noun Literature is creative writing such as novels, short stories, poems and plays, especially ones that are considered to be of a high standard. She studied Australian literature at university. It's not great literature, but it's a good read.

noun The literature on a particular subject is what has been written about it. I've read all the available literature on rock climbing. I followed up the references in the literature. Please send me your sales literature on the new range of computers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective literary He uses a lot of old-fashioned, literary language. She writes literary fiction.

form.definition: noun A litre is a metric unit of capacity. It is the amount of liquid that fits into 1000 cubic centimetres. I bought a litre of milk.
form.note: ... NOTEThe symbol for this is l.

form.definition: noun Litter is rubbish that has been left lying around in an open space. There was litter all over the side of the roadcans, cigarette butts and lolly papers.
verb If someone litters a place, they make it untidy by leaving things scattered around. Don't litter the parkpick up that can and put it in the bin! The house was littered with books and papers.
noun A litterbug is someone who drops rubbish in the street or other open spaces. The picnic place has been ruined by the inconsiderate behaviour of litterbugs.

adjective If something is little, it is small in size. Often you use this word to show that something is either rather nice or rather insignificant. She takes that little dog with her everywhere. There's even a little bag to put things in. What are these little bits of glass for? The envelopes were decorated with little drawings.
adjective If something is little, it is small in amount. Add a little bit of milk to the mixture. Just wait a little while.
adjective A little child is a young child. Don't be mean to Daisyshe's only little. When I was little, I used to walk to school. I've got to mind my little brother. Who's daddy's little girl, then?
adverb Little also means hardly at all or very rarely. She seemed little troubled by the allegations. I go there very little these days.
noun Little means not much or almost nothing. Suzy has done little to help. He said little about the experience.
4 a little (a) You use a little to indicate you think something is so only to a small extent. You can also say a bit. 'Does it hurt?' 'A little.' He seemed a little upset.
(b) adjective A little refers to a small amount of something. I've only got a little money. I'll have a little cream with my coffee, thanks. There's a little dirt on your sleeve.

dictionary.entry:
livelIv <for the verb>; <for adjective and adverb senses> la:Iv
verb If you live somewhere, that is where your home is. How long have you lived in Australia? Kyle lives next door to me.
verb If you say that someone lives somewhere, you mean that they seem to spend all their time there. Some of these guys just live at the gym. Saretta's living at the library these days.
verb If you live with someone, you share the same accommodation and usually have a sexual relationship as well. This is Matt, the guy I live with. We lived together for two years before we got married.
verb If you live in a certain way, your life is like that. I'm sick of living out of a suitcase. I don't know how people can live in such conditions. He likes to live dangerously.
verb If a person or animal is living, they are alive. He lived at the beginning of the century.
adjective If a person or animal is described as live, they are not dead. This is used only directly before a noun; compare it with alive. That crate contains live monkeys. They put a live snake in his bed.
5a adjective A live radio or television program is broadcast at the same time as it happens. It is not recorded and then broadcast later.
adverb If a program is broadcast live, it is broadcast at the same time as it happens. And now we go over live to our correspondent in Washington.
adjective If something is live, it is carrying an electric current. Another word for this is active. Be carefulthat powerpoint is live. b adjective The live wire in an electric cord is the one that carries the current. It is covered in brown insulation, or red in the case of some older cords. Compare this with earth and neutral.
adjective A live bomb or shell is one that is capable of exploding. They used live ammunition in the training exercise. The children found an old grenade that was still live.
8 live for If you live for something, that is the most important thing in your life. Perry lives for surfing. 9 live off If you live off someone or something, that is your source of income. I got a job because I didn't want to live off my parents any longer. He patented the invention and lived off the royalties. 10 live on (a) If you live on a certain amount of money, that is the amount that you have to pay your expenses. Now that Jack's retired, we have less to live on. How can we possibly live on $200 a week?
(b) If you live on something, that is the food that you eat. You should get a healthy dietyou can't live on noodles and chocolate biscuits.
11 live with If you live with something, you get used to it and put up with it. You may not like the decision, but you're just going to have to live with it. He has to live with the pain.
... BE CAREFULwith the pronunciation of this word. The adjective and adverb meanings (4, 5, 6 and 7) are pronounced differently from the verb. ... WORD FAMILYnoun See life. adjective See living. noun See living.

form.definition: noun Your livelihood is what provides you with an income to live on. Farming is their livelihood. I do deliveries, so if my licence is cancelled I've lost my livelihood.

adjective If you are lively, you are full of energy and vitality. Sam's a really lively childhe exhausts his mother! I'm not feeling very lively todaylet's just stay in and read. The party began to get more lively after midnight.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun liveliness

form.definition: noun Your liver is a part of your body which helps to purify your blood and get rid of unwanted substances. <Heavy drinking had damaged her liver>.
noun Livestock is farm animals, such as cattle and sheep.
adjective If someone is livid, they are extremely angry. I was livid when I found out.
adjective If something is livid, it is dark with bruising. His ankle was swollen and livid. She had livid bruises all over her arm.
adjective If a person, animal or plant is living, it is alive. Aunt Jane is my only living relative. He is probably Australia's greatest living artist. All living things need water.
noun Your living is how you earn an income to pay your expenses. He makes his living as a plumber. What does she do for a living? The farm has given us a good living.
3 living conditions Your living conditions are the standard of housing, food and clothing that you have. Living conditions in the refugee camps are appalling.
4 living room Living room is another word for lounge room.[qr
noun A lizard is a reptile, usually small, with a long tail and rough dry skin.

verb If you load something such as a vehicle or trailer, you put things into it in order to transport them somewhere. We loaded the car with rubbish and took it all to the dump. They're loading the crates onto the truck. The ship is loading and will leave tomorrow. Are we all loaded up now?

verb If you load a machine, you put something inside it to prepare it for action. He loaded the gun with a single bullet. Make sure the camera is loaded with film. Could you load the dishwasher for me? You load the detergent here. 3a noun A load of something is an amount that is transported or processed at one time. We had another load of firewood delivered. With three kids I do at least two loads of washing every day. It won't all fit inwe'll have to do it in two loads. b noun A load of something is a large amount of it. I've got a load of ironing to do. Sally spent the weekend marking a load of essays. The whole theory is a load of rubbish.

4 load down If you are loaded down, you've got too much work and find it hard to manage. I'm not seeing anyone this weekI'm loaded down with essays to write. He's really loaded down with money worries.

5 loaded In informal language, if you say that someone is loaded, you mean that they have a lot of money. They must be loadedlook at the size of their house! 6 loads of In informal language, if you say there are loads of people or things, you mean there are a great many or a lot. Come on, join the partythere's loads of food!

dictionary.entry:
loafl@Ufloaves\minion0\(/\times0\lovz\minion0\/))\optima0\1\minion0\nounA loaf is an amount of bread that is baked separately and is enough for several servings. Loaves can have various different shapes and
verb If someone loafs around, they spend their time without doing anything useful. He loafs around the house all day watching television. There was a gang of youths loafing on the street corner.
... WORD FAMILYnoun loafer Get moving, you lazy loafer!

form.definition: noun Loam is a type of soil which is rich and fertile.

noun A loan is an amount of money that you borrow, usually from a bank, and have to pay back over a certain period of time, with interest. We're off to apply for a home loan before we decide to buy the house. ...a personal loan.

2 on loan If something is on loan, it has been lent for a period of time. This sculpture is on loan from the Australian National Gallery. You may have up to twelve books on loan at one time. I'm afraid that tape is out on loan at the moment.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See lend. noun loan I had the loan of his car while he was overseas.

form.definition: adjective If you are loath to do something, you are reluctant or unwilling to do it. I am loath to accept her money.
verb If you loathe someone or something, you dislike them very much. I really loathe that man! The kids all loathe sprouts.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun loathing She was filled with loathing for him.

form.definition: verb If you lob a ball in tennis, you hit it high in the air and over your opponent's head so that they have to run back to hit it.
noun In a hotel, a lobby is the entrance hall or foyer. I'll meet you in the lobby at seven.

noun A lobby or a lobby group is a number of people who try to influence the government or other authorities to act in a particular way. The anti-smoking lobby wants the Government to ban cigarette advertising in sport.
verb If you lobby someone to do something, you try to persuade them to do what you want. They lobbied the government to increase education funding.
adjective If something is local, it is in your area or suburb. Our local school has five hundred pupils. He's a well-known local character.
noun If something is local, it is concerned with a small area of the country. Local government elections are held every four years. Local calls are untimed.
adjective A local anaesthetic affects only a small part of your body. I had the wart removed under local anaesthetic.

noun A local is a person who lives in your area. I know himhe's a local. His family have been here for years. 5 noun In informal language, your local is a hotel or pub near where you live and work, and where you often go. Come and have a drink at the local with me.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective localised (or localized) There was severe localised storm activity.noun locality (localities) Is there a post office in the locality?

form.definition: verb If you locate something, you look for it and manage to find out where it is. Doctors haven't been able to locate the cause of the pain. I'm trying to locate Mr Ferguson.
verb If something is located somewhere, that is where it is. The post office is located in the centre of the town. They haven't yet decided where to locate the new factory.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun location Do you know the location of the post office?

form.definition: noun A lock is a mechanical or electronic device which can be opened only with a key or by knowing a particular sequence of letters and numbers. The burglar forced the lock on the window. All the hotel rooms have electronic locks. There is a combination lock on the safe. Copying is prevented by a software lock.
verb If you lock something, you fasten or secure it so that it can be opened only with a key or password. The door's lockedI can't get in. Don't forget to lock the car.

verb If you lock something somewhere, you put it where it can be reached only with a key or password. I've locked the jewellery in the safe. The dog's been locked in the laundry all night. Poisons should be kept locked away.

noun A lock of hair is a small curl as it grows onyour head, or especially a section of your hair which has been cut off. She pushed an unruly lock of hair back from her forehead. He keeps a lock of his daughter's baby hair in his wallet.
4 lock up (a) If the authorities lock someone up, they put them in prison. People like that ought to be locked up.

(b) If you lock up, you shut and lock all your doors and windows and doors so that nobody[qrcan get in. The manager locked up the shop. Can you lock up before you come to bed? 5 under lock and key If something is kept under lock and key, it is stored in a locked container or room. Firearms must be kept under lock and key.

noun A locker is a small cupboard that can be locked. Lockers are usually made of metal and grouped together in public places. You can use one for a short period if you pay a fee. Each child has a locker for their possessions. I left my luggage in a locker at the airport. You can leave your clothes in this locker while you're in the pool.

noun A locket is a piece of jewellery which opens so that you can put something such as a picture of someone you love inside it. Usually you wear it around your neck on a chain. She wore a heart-shaped locket with his photo inside.
noun A locksmith is someone who fits and repairs locks, and cuts keys. I locked myself out, so I had to call a locksmith.
noun A locomotive is a railway engine.
noun A lodge is a small house or hut in the country or the mountains where people go for their holidays. When we went skiing we stayed at a lodge just a few minutes from the slopes.
verb If you lodge with someone, you rent a room in their house and often you share meals with them.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun lodger We took in lodgers to boost our income.

form.definition: noun A loft is the space in a building between the ceiling and the roof where people sometimes store things. He put the empty cases in the loft. We're thinking of having the loft converted to a study for Jenny.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is attic.

form.definition: adjective Lofty is a rather literary word meaning 'very high'. We lifted our eyes to the lofty mountain peaks.
adjective If an idea or aim is lofty, it is very fine and noble, but possibly not very practical. How can we translate these lofty sentiments into action?
adjective If someone is lofty in their manner, they are rather arrogant and dismissive. His lofty manner upset many of the staff.
noun A log is a length from a branch or the trunk of a tree. He put another log on the fire. The logs are floated downstream to the mill. The snake made its home in a hollow log.
verb If you log an area of forest, you cut down the trees for their timber. There are few areas of forest that have not yet been logged.

noun A log is a written record of events or measurements that is made as they happen. The ship's log revealed that the weather had been calm that night. If you make any photocopies, you have to enter them in this log. I kept a log of every call I made for a month.
verb If you log something, you note or record it. I logged the distance I ran each day.
4 log in or on If you log in or log on to a computer network, you gain access to it.
5 log off or out If you log off or log out from a computer network, you finish using the system you were connected to.

adjective If reasoning is logical, it follows a formal system of drawing conclusions from known facts. Be logicalhow can you possibly expect to finish in that period of time? His plan was logical but it didn't work.
adjective If something is logical, it is reasonable or what you would expect. We were both going to the same place, so it was logical to travel together.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun logic He used logic to solve the problem.adverb logically Calm down and try to think about it logically.

form.definition: verb If you loiter somewhere, you hang around or remain in the same spot without doing anything in particular. Don't loiter on the way home from schoolwe're going out at six. A suspicious character was seen loitering outside the premises.
noun A lolly is a sweet food to suck or chew for enjoyment. The children are always asking for lollies.

adjective If someone or something is described as lone, they are on their own, or they are the only one in a particular situation. We saw a lone figure on the top of the hill. These three were the lone survivors of the crash.
2 lone parent A lone parent is someone who is looking after their child or children alone, without the help of a partner.
adjective If you are lonely, you feel sad because you miss the company of other people. She spent a lonely childhood on a remote cattle station. It's easy to be lonely in the big city.
adjective If a place is lonely, few people go there. It is usually a long way from a town or city. The crate was washed up on a lonely beach on the south coast.

dictionary.entry:
longlON (adjective and adverb forms longer, longest
adjective If something is long, it covers a large distance from one end to the other. The opposite of this is short. She has long blond hair. It's quite a long way away. I've got a long list of things to do. How long is the shelf? The road is five kilometres long.
adjective If something is long, it lasts a considerable time. He made a long speech. I need a long holiday. I've been waiting a long time. The movie was three hours long.
adverb If something lasts long, it lasts a considerable time. I've long admired her. They fought long and hard. How long have you been here? Did you wait long? This won't take long. Stay longer next time. Who's been working longest?
verb If you long to do something, you want to do it very much. He longs to see Greece again before he dies. 4 any longer Any longer means 'in the future'. Do you need this any longer? I won't be going there any longer. He refused to support her any longer.
5 as or so long as If something will happen as long as or so long as something else happens, it will happen only if the other thing does too. We'll be safe as long as we stay here. You can go out so long as you're back by eleven.
6 before long Before long means 'soon'. He was back before long, carrying a bottle of wine. They're going to have problems before long.
7 for long For long means 'for a long time'. I bet he won't stay there for long. Will you be away for long?
8 long for If you long for something, you want it very much. By the time we finished I was longing for a beer. I was just longing for her to make a fool of herself. 9 No longer means 'not any more'. I can no longer tolerate this behaviour. The suitcase was no longer there.
10 so long In informal language, so long is a way of saying 'goodbye'.
... WORD FAMILYnoun See length. verb See lengthen. adjective longing She cast a longing look at the cake.noun longing I felt a longing to see him again.

form.definition: noun Longitude is the position of a place east or west of a line that passes through Greenwich in England. It is measured in degrees. Lithgow is at a longitude of 150 degrees east.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with latitude.

form.definition: verb If you look at something, you direct your vision in that direction. She turned to look at the car. Look! There's Ben. I looked out of the window and saw him. Why don't you look in the drawer. He looked me up and down.
verb If you look at something such as a book, you read bits of it in a casual way. I've looked at the report but I haven't read it properly yet. I looked through the magazine while I waited.

noun If you have a look at something, you see it and pay some attention to it. Have a look at this and tell me what you think. Paul brought in his cartoons and everyone wanted a look. Shall we have a look in the museum?

verb If something looks a certain way, it appears like that. The hill looks pretty steep. You look happy today! It looks as though it'll rain. Things look bleak for the economy. He looks like a pig. Labor looks like winning the election.

noun If something has a certain look, it has that appearance. The cattle had a healthy look. What do you think of my new look? A fresh coat of paint will improve the look of the place. I've tried to give the design a modern look.

interjection You can use look at the beginning of a sentence to emphasise what you say or to introduce a suggestion. Look, you're really going to have to work harder. Look, it doesn't matter, I'll come back tomorrow. Look, why don't you let me do it?

6 look after If you look after someone, you care for them. I spent a year at home looking after the baby. He's got a large family to look after. I'll stay here and look after her, you go for help. 7 look for If you look for something, you try to find it. I'm looking for my car keyshave you seen them? We're looking for someone to manage the sales team. I'm looking for something to give my mother.

8 look forward to If you look forward to something, you are happy and excited about what's going to happen in the future. Jake's been looking forward to the party for weeks. I'm looking forward to the day Jade goes to kindergarten. 9 look out If you tell someone to look out, you are warning them to be careful about some danger. Look out, there's a car coming! You need to look out that she doesn't take all the credit.

10 look out for If you look out for something, you pay attention so that you'll be sure not to miss seeing it. Look out for the postmanI'm expecting a parcel. I've been looking out for a nice vase for ages.
If you look something over, you check or inspect it. I looked my essay over one more time before handing it in. You ought to get a mechanic to look the car over before you buy it.

12 looks Someone's looks are their physical appearance. Jill has dazzling good looks and a personality to match. 13 look up If you look something up, you check it in a book, database or other source of reference. I looked up their number in the phone book. Look up my name and see what it says.
14 look up to If you look up to someone, you admire and respect them. I've always looked up to my auntshe achieved a lot in her life.
noun A lookout is a place from which you have a good view over the surrounding land or sea. At the lookout we took photos of the city below.
noun A lookout is also someone who keeps watch to warn of danger. The railway workers posted a lookout further up the track.
noun A loom is a machine which weaves thread into cloth.
verb If something looms, it seems large and close and threatening. The vast cliff loomed over the two small figures. Suddenly a tanker loomed out of the darkness.
verb If an event looms, it is due to happen soon and you are worried about it. My exams are looming at the end of the month.[qr

noun A loop is formed when something such as a piece of string crosses over itself to form a round shape. It may be knotted in place. The present was decorated with loops of ribbon. A simple bow has two loops and two loose ends. Slip the handle through this loop. I stretched out the rope to get rid of the loops.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb loop Loop the hose neatly and hang it up.

form.definition: A loophole is part of a law or contract which unintentionally allows you to avoid punishment or some obligation because of its poor wording. The government is acting to close loopholes in the tax laws.
adjective If clothes are loose, they do not fit closely. In this heat you need to wear loose clothes.
adjective If something such as a knot or grip is loose, it is not tight or firm.
adjective If something is loose, it is not properly fixed or tight. It is wobbly and may become detached. The door handle's looseI'll have to screw it back in. The catch had worked loose.
adjective If something is loose, it is not attached to anything. A few loose sheets of paper fell on the floor.
adjective If something is loose, it is not in a container. A few loose pins were lying on the table. They sell loose nuts by weight.
4 at a loose end If you are at a loose end, you don't have enough to do. The kids are often at a loose end during the holidays.
5 on the loose If someone is on the loose, they are free. The prisoner escaped from custody and is now on the loose.
6 set loose If you set a person or animal loose, you allow them to go free. He set his horse loose for a run around the paddock.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb loosen He loosened his tie and sat down to relax.

form.definition: noun Loot is money or goods that have been stolen. He agreed to take part in the robbery in return for a share of the loot.

verb If someone loots a place, they steal valuable goods from it, at a time when normal conditions of law and order are absent. The presidential palace was looted by rebel soldiers. The newspapers carried reports of looting in the flooded town.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun looter Shops were ransacked by looters during the riot.

form.definition: verb If you lop something, you cut part of it off. They lopped the top off the tree. I just wanted my hair trimmed, not lopped like this! The new manager has lopped our budget.

adjective If something is lopsided, it is crooked, or its two sides aren't straight or even. The picture's a bit lopsided on the wall. He gave a lopsided grin. I feel lopsided with all the heavy stuff in this bag.
noun A lord is a man who has power over other people. He acts as if he's our lord and master.
noun A lorry is a truck.
verb If you lose something, it is missing and you don't know where it is. I've lost my glasses againhave you seen them? I never buy nice gloves because I always lose them.
verb If you lose something, you no longer have it because it's been destroyed. They lost their home in the bushfire. He lost his sight at the age of seven.
verb If you lose a member of your family, they die. I lost both my parents in a car smash. It's a terrible thing to lose a child.

verb If you lose something, you no longer have it. It is gone from you. She lost her seat on the board. I've lost patience with him. They seem to have lost their enthusiasm. Damn, now I've lost count. I lost the thread of what she was saying.
verb If you lose something such as a match, race, argument, battle or court case, you do not win it. You are defeated. Australia lost in the third round.
verb If a business loses money, it makes a loss rather than a profit. They lost over $1 000 000 last year. We lost money on the deal.

verb If your watch loses time, it doesn't keep up with the right time. The time it shows is earlier than it really is, and the difference gradually becomes greater. I reckon that your clock's losing a couple of minutes a day.
7 lose out If you lose out, you don't have an opportunity that other people have. They'd already eaten the cake and so I lost out.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See loss. adjective See lost. noun loser The loser has to pay the costs. He's a real losercan't do anything right.

form.definition: noun You make a loss in business if your costs exceed your earnings. The opposite of this is profit. Our total loss this year exceeds$500 000. I made a loss on the deal. Be sure to claim the loss against your tax.
noun A loss is losing something. The insurance policy covers loss and accidental damage. He sought compensation for his loss of sight. She suffered a severe loss of dignity.
noun A loss is a defeat. His record is twelve wins, seven draws and three losses.
noun A loss is the death of a relative or friend. We offer our sympathy for your recent loss.
noun A loss is a disadvantage. His resignation was a great loss to them. If they don't want to take my advice, it's their loss not mine.

6 a dead loss In informal language, if you say that someone or something is a dead loss, you mean that they are no use to you. The whole thing's a dead losswe may as well give up now. You can't rely on Frankhe's a dead loss.
verb Lost is the past tense and past participle of lose.

adjective If you are lost, you don't know where you are and you can't find your way to where you want to go. Without a map I was soon lost. There's a special meeting point for parents and lost children. She's always taking in lost puppies.
adjective If you are lost, you are confused. Could you explain that bit againI'm lost. I've got completely lostis she the sister of the other woman?

noun A lot is a certain amount of something or number of things or people that go together. Can I have two lots of jelly? We made so many we had to bake them in three lots. I'd only just finished with those when the next lot arrived. Can you lot give me a hand?
noun At an auction a lot is one or more items that are sold as a unit. What am I bid for lot 673?
noun A lot is a piece of land in a subdivision. That's where we're going to build, lot 2845.
noun Your lot in life is what happens to you, especially the events you don't control. There's no point in complaining about your lot.

5 a lot (a) A lot means a large amount or number. They don't have a lot, but what they've got they share. She must earn a lot in that job. The children certainly eat a lot. 'How many people were there?' 'A lotmaybe 200.'
(b) A lot means 'to a great degree' or 'to a great extent'. He looks a lot like you. I enjoyed it a lot.
(c) A lot also means 'often'. We go to the movies a lot.

6 a lot of A lot of something is a large amount or number. Carmen put a lot of chilli in the sauce. Tere made a lot of new friends when she came from Peru. He's put on a lot of weight. She's in a lot of pain.

7 by lot If you decide something by lot or by drawing lots, you decide it by a random method (such as drawing pieces of paper out of a box) so as to be fair to everyone. The order of the candidates on the ballot paper is determined by lot.
8 lots (a) In informal language, lots means 'a large amount or number'. 'Have you got enough money?' 'Yes, lots.' Come on, we've still got lots to do.
(b) In informal language, lots means 'to a great degree' or 'to a great extent'. I like him lots. He's helped me lots.
(c) In informal language, lots also means 'often'. I go to the beach lots in summer.
9 lots of In informal language, lots of something is a large amount or number. He gave me lots of books to read. Lots of the time I'm really bored. Lots of the other girls are going.
10 the lot The lot refers to the whole amount or number of something. She bought a box of chocolates and ate the lot. They can go to hell, the lot of them!
noun A lotion is a liquid that you put on your skin to clean, protect or heal it. You should put on some suntan lotion before you go to the beach. Catherine uses a moisturising lotion every day.

noun A lottery is a gambling game where people buy tickets and win a money prize if the number on their ticket is chosen at random. Lotteries are often run by state governments to raise money for the state.
noun Lotto is another word for bingo. Some State governments also run a gambling game of similar nature, called Lotto, in which you bet on which sequence of numbered balls will be selected.
adjective If something is loud, it is noisy. You can hear it very clearly. The TV's too loudturn it down! He called my name in a loud voice.

adjective If something is loud, it is very bold and bright in colour and usually striking in design. The magazine attracted attention with its loud cover. Avoid loud shirts and ties if you're going for an interview.

3 out loud If you say something out loud, you say it so that it can be heard instead of just thinking or whispering it. Say that again out loud! Most of the staff are afraid to criticise her out loud.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun loudness

form.definition: noun A loudspeaker is a device through which you can make speech louder, so that it can be heard in a hall or other public place.
form.note: ... COMPARE THIS WORDwith speaker, which is normally used for similar devices on audio equipment.

form.definition: noun A lounge or lounge room is a room in your house where you can relax. It may be furnished with things such as a lounge suite, television, video, CD player and bookcases.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is living room. 2 noun A lounge in a hotel or airport is a room or large area furnished with chairs where you can sit and wait.

form.definition: noun A lounge is a couch or sofa. 4 lounge about or around If you lounge about or around somewhere, you do very little and generally behave in a very lazy way. I'm sick of the boys lounging about the house all day. There seemed to be a lot of staff just lounging around.
5 lounge suite A lounge suite is a set of matching furniture consisting of a sofa and usually two armchairs.
noun A louse is a small insect without wings which can live in people's hair or bedding.
noun You can call someone who is mean and dishonest a louse. Fancy cheating his friends like thatwhat a louse!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See lousy.

form.definition: adjective In informal language, if you say someone is lousy, you mean that they are reluctant to spend money. Another word for this is stingy. Don't be lousylet's buy the larger one.
adjective In informal language, if you say that someone or something is lousy, you mean that they are mean or unpleasant. I'll get him, the lousy bastard! What a lousy trick to play on you!
adjective In informal language, if you say something is lousy, you mean that it's of very poor quality. The food at the hotel was lousy.
In informal language, if you say you feel lousy, you mean that you feel sick. I've been feeling lousy with flu all week.
4 lousy with In informal language, if you say someone is lousy with something, you mean they have a lot of it. Geoff's absolutely lousy with money.
noun A lout is a young man who is very rough and rude. Kit was abused by a couple of louts on the tram.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective loutish

form.definition: noun Love is a very strong feeling of affection for someone. Anna felt growing love for him.
verb If you love someone, you have a lot of affection for them and care for them very much. They are very important to you. I love my two girlsI couldn't live without them.
verb If you love something, you care a lot about it and it is very important to you. Terry still loves his old teddy bear. Surely everyone loves freedom and justice?
verb If you love something, you like or enjoy it very much. Jackie loves ice-cream. I love going to the beach. I love the way you've renovated the kitchen. The children love to bounce on the sofa.
noun Someone's love is the person that they are romantically involved with. Go ontell us all about your new love.
noun In tennis, love is a score of zero. Perdita leads, three games to love. 5 fall in love If you fall in love with someone, you start to love them romantically. We fell in love over the summer.
6 in love If you are in love with someone, you love them romantically. They may or may not also love you. Juan and Maria are so much in love.
7 make love If you make love with someone, you have sex with them.

8 with love from People use with love from as an ending for letters or as a message in cards or with presents if they are related to each other or know each other well. It does not mean that they feel romantic love. See you soon, with love from Milly.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See lovely. adjective lovable He's a very lovable childalways happy and helpful.noun lover He's a lover of fine wine. Jeanne has had a secret lover for two years.adjective loving She gave him a loving smile.

dictionary.entry:
lovely`lV vli:lovelierloveliest 1 adjective If someone or something is lovely, they are pleasant and generally liked by people. Mrs Smith is a lovely lady. It's a lovely day. We had a lovely time at the zoo. This pie is lovely. I bought a lovely new dress. She's got a lovely voice.
adjective If someone is lovely, they are beautiful. Leyla is really lovely, with her dark hair and green eyes.

form.definition: adjective If something is low, it is close to the ground or to the bottom of something. The opposite of this is high. I was struck by a low branch. Temperatures were in the low thirties.

adjective If something is low, it measures a small amount from bottom to top. It doesn't extend far off the ground. The opposite of this is tall or high. The factory is a long, low building. She rested her feet on a low stool.

adjective Low also means small in amount or degree. The opposite of this is high. Look at these low prices! They have a low standard of education. This dish is low in fat. Temperatures have been lower than average. Our reserves are running low.
adjective If a container is low, there is not much in it. It is nearly empty. The dam is really lowI wish it would rain. We're getting low on petrol.
adjective If a battery is low, it has hardly any energy or charge left in it.

adjective If you feel low, you feel sad or depressed. He's been really low since he lost his job. 5 adjective If you speak in a low voice, the pitch of your voice is deep. You may also speak softly. He gave a low moan.
adjective In informal language, if you say that someone's behaviour is low, you mean that it is morally bad. He left his wife and five childrenhow low can you get? That was a pretty low thing to do.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See lower. verb See lower.

form.definition: adjective Lower is the comparative form of low.

adjective The lower part of something is the part nearer the bottom. The opposite of this is upper. The bullet smashed his lower jaw. I sat on the lower deck of the ferry. 2a verb If you lower something, you make it less in amount or degree. They lowered their prices by 15%. The temperature is lowered until the gas becomes liquid. She refused to lower her ambitions. b verb If you lower your voice, you make it less loud. She lowered her voice so that the children wouldn't hear.
verb If you lower something, you move it downwards. She lowered the basket on a rope. He lowered himself into a chair.
verb If you lower your eyes, you look downwards. She lowered her eyes when he came into the room.

adjective If someone is loyal, they continue to support a person or a cause even though things are difficult. Ali has been a loyal friend to me. ... WORD FAMILYnoun loyalty (loyalties) I never doubted Corinne's loyalty.
noun A lozenge is a small tablet or sweet that you suck to relieve a sore throat.
abbreviation for liquefied petroleum gas. This is a mixture of gases which is stored under pressure in metal containers and can be used as a fuel in things such as gas barbecues.[qr

dictionary.entry:
L-plate`El-plEIt
noun An L-plate is a small square sign with the letter L in black on a yellow background. When you're learning to drive you must display these signs on the front and back of your car so other drivers can see them. He's on his L-plates now.
... A SHORT FORMof this is Ls: Naomi got her Ls today.

form.definition: abbreviation for Limited, which may be used after the name of a company, to indicate that it is a limited company. I work for Smith and Rogers Ltd.
verb If you lubricate a machine, you add something such as oil or grease so that the moving parts will slide over each other more easily.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun lubrication

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is lucid, they are clear and easy to understand. He gave a lucid account of the problem.

adjective If someone who is sick is lucid, they are able to understand what is going on. They are not unconscious or delirious. Grandma's very sick but she's still lucid. He was able to settle his affairs during brief lucid intervals.

noun Luck is the way things turn out well or badly for people as the result of chance. He's had a lot of bad luck lately. It was my good luck that she was there. I'll just have to hope for better luck next time.
noun Luck is also good fortune or a good result. She wished me luck in the exams. I couldn't believe my luck when I won the prize.
3 bad luck! You say bad luck! to someone to encourage them when they haven't succeeded in something, although they might have tried hard. Bad luck, you were so close!
4 good luck! You say good luck! to someone before they do something that they want to do well in. Good luck in the high jump today! Good luck for your presentation!

5 pushing your luck In informal language, if you say someone is pushing their luck, you mean that they are taking a chance that probably won't be successful. They are being too ambitious. It's all very well asking for one day off, but two is pushing her luck a bit.

6 worse luck In informal language, if you say that something is going to happen or has happened and add worse luck, you mean you are displeased about it. I hurt my knee at training today so I won't be able to play at the weekend, worse luck!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb luckily Luckily I had a spare set of keys, so I could let myself in.adjective lucky (luckier, luckiest) Isn't she luckywinning a trip to France! You were lucky to catch me.

form.definition: adjective If something is lucrative, it brings in a large amount of money. Within five years their partnership was very lucrative. He holds several lucrative patents.

adjective If something is ludicrous, it is absolutely ridiculous. It is very foolish. His suggestion was ludicrous. Vimala was wearing a ludicrous outfit. It's ludicrous to think we'll be ready next week.

verb In informal language, if you say you lug something somewhere, you mean you take it there with great difficulty, usually because it's heavy. Don't tell me I've lugged all these heavy pots over here for nothing! I'm sick of lugging this bag around. She lugged the toddler up the stairs.
noun Your luggage is all the things that you take with you when you travel. I haven't got much luggagejust a suitcase and my tennis racquet.
adjective If something is lukewarm, it is warm but not hot. The blouse should be washed in lukewarm water. By now the soup was lukewarm and disgusting.
adjective If someone is lukewarm in their attitude, they are not very excited or interested. We received a rather lukewarm reception. He was always lukewarm about the idea.
noun A lull is a period of calm and quiet in the middle of a very busy or noisy period. There was a lull in the shooting, and the soldiers relaxed for a while.
verb If you lull someone, you make them feel calm and settled. She lulled the baby to sleep. The recent stability has lulled investors. We mustn't be lulled into a false sense of security.
noun A lullaby is a song that you sing to a baby to make it go to sleep.
adjective If something is luminous, it shines in the dark, or reflects light well. The walls are decorated with luminous designs. The road signs have a special luminous surface.
noun A lump of something is a chunk or piece of something solid. She took a lump of clay and began to mould it. He passed me a lump of chocolate.

noun A lump in something is a swelling or uneven part. A big lump came up on his head where the beam hit him. All breast lumps should be carefully investigated. I couldn't get the lumps out of the sauce. The old sofa was full of lumps.

verb In informal language, if you say you lump things together, you mean that you put them together without much care or attention. She lumped her clothes into the suitcase and dashed for the bus. They lumped us all together in the one small room.
4 lump in your throat If you have a lump in your throat, you suddenly feel sad or emotional about something and almost cry. She could hardly speak for the lump in her throat.
5 lump sum A lump sum is an amount of money that is paid together instead of as separate sums or instalments. When he left his job, his lump sum included superannuation and holiday pay.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective lumpy (lumpier, lumpiest) The mattress is all lumpy.

form.definition: adjective A lunar thing or event has to do with the moon. There's going to be a lunar eclipse next Friday.
noun A lunatic is an old-fashioned word for someone who is seriously mentally disturbed.

noun If you call someone a lunatic, you mean their behaviour is extremely foolish and often dangerous. Don't be a lunaticyou'll get us all killed. ... WORD FAMILYadjective lunatic He's got this lunatic idea of quitting his job. She's a lunatic driver.noun lunacy It's sheer lunacyit'll never work out.
noun Lunch is the meal in the middle of the day. I take sandwiches to work for lunch. Sunday lunch was always a roast leg of lamb. He invited me to lunch.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb lunch We'll lunch by the river.

form.definition: noun Your lungs are the organs in your chest with which you breathe. He had to have part of one lung removed.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective lung ...lung cancer.

form.definition: verb If you lunge at someone, you make a sudden, unexpected movement towards them. He lunged at me and hit me in the chest.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun lunge

form.definition: verb If you lurch, you move in an unsteady way with sudden jerky movements. The drunk lurched in front of the oncoming car. The bus lurched off down the road.

2 leave someone in the lurch In informal language, if you say someone leaves you in the lurch, you mean they don't help you when you really need them. Don't leave me in the lurch after we've been through so much together!
(<plural form lurgies) noun If you have a lurgy, you have caught a disease such as a cold or cough.

adjective If something is lurid, it is brightly and often rather strangely coloured. She was wearing a lurid pink outfit. They serve really lurid cocktails. They'd painted it a lurid green. The magazines' lurid covers compete for attention. 2 adjective If a story or picture is lurid, it is shocking, usually because it includes details of sex or violence. She revelled in all the lurid details of the crime. He reads a lot of lurid horror novels.
verb If someone lurks somewhere, they wait or loiter there, often to commit a crime. I could see a figure lurking in the darkness.

verb If an idea or suspicion lurks in your mind, it remains there in the background although you are not really thinking about it. The plan to start my own business is still lurking at the back of my mind. I couldn't shake off the lurking suspicion that something was wrong.
noun In informal language, a lurk is a very easy way to make money which often involves something dishonest. He gets to work late and comes home earlywhat a lurk!
adjective If something is luscious, it tastes very good or looks very attractive. She served a luscious creamy dessert.
adjective If plants are lush, they are very green and growing well. The cattle grew fat on the lush pasture.
noun Lust is strong sexual desire. He was inflamed with lust.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective lustful

form.definition: adjective If something is luxuriant, it is thick and plentiful and growing well. The garden was a luxuriant mass of flowers. She has long, luxuriant hair.
noun Luxury is an extremely pleasant and expensive lifestyle. She's lived in luxury all her life. I really enjoyed the luxury of the five-star hotel.

noun A luxury is something that you don't really need but which makes your life more pleasant or comfortable. I allowed myself a small bar of chocolate as a luxury. It's such a luxury to have a washing machine! We're going to have to cut down on the luxuries now Fernando's lost his job.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective luxurious

form.definition: verb Lying is the present participle of lie.
noun A lyrebird is a ground-dwelling bird of Australian forests. The males have a tail with large curved feathers, which they use for display. The lyrebird appears on the ten cent coin.[fa[xp
